The fact that Columbia the supercontinent lasted for 600 million years, It was the continent that lasted the longest.     1:12 The Hadean Eon was the first eon of earth, all of earth was scorching. But it wont stay like this. Water could have been existing here. In this eon, earth is bombarded by tons of meteorites. With oceans of lava, Life is inhospitable in earth. It will cool down over time. Earth in the Hadean  Eon was spinning once every around 4 hours. Because of this, Earth was flattened a bit. The moon could also have been 60,000km away.  2:29 Earth cools down. But still, it is deadly    4:07 Earth was said to have oceans in 4300 million years ago, yet it has no life, Its first ocean was the Hadean Ocean. But lets just follow the timeline.    8:04 The Eoarchean begins, earth is 90 degrees Â°C and water starts. Earth is covered in water as it cools down. 9:47 Earth gets visible lakes on it. Yet it will take alot of time for a global ocean. Tectonic plates start here as well. The moon is now 100,000 km (estimated) so tides are extreme.      12:46 Hydrothermal vents start the seeding of life. It is likely that life started here. The first tiny islands appear. Theres no oxygen here yet. 13:35 The Paleoarchean starts. Nothing really happens except the islands get bigger as volcanoes rise.    18:45  The Mesoarchean starts and also nothing really happens, except earth spins slower (now at 9.6 hrs) and cells multiply. They can learn to eat sunlight soon. Earths oceans are green because of the amount of iron in them. Iron was abundant in the oceans during this time. Until oxygen came.     24:25 The Neoarchean comes around. The major supercontinent, Kenorland forms, It is said to be pretty big. But nothing is on the land yet. 25:29 Kenorland breaks apart, with the first island that appeared merging with another. 27:11 Oxygen gets introduced around here, but this would change earth forever. And it will entirely. 27:49 The Siderian doesnâ€™t really have to do with the Iron Banding and the Huronian Glaciation. But the iron banding is a massive event.   27:49 because pf the oxygen amount, it gets mixed with the iron in the ocean, creating iron oxide, which is why earth turned red. Your blood also has iron oxide too.   With the amount of ocean, the threshold of the iron oxide makes it nearly black Because a little makes it appear red, but with the mass of the earths oceans are green, it is a very deep red.   The Huronian glaciation begins, turning the earth into a snowball. 29:07     33:51 Earth returns as the deep red, yet iron oxide is still abundant. Atlantica is also assembled.   36:23 1850 million years ago, An asteroid hit into what is modern day Canada. It hit on a tiny island. But it ceased all iron banding on earth temporarily. After some 600 thousand years, the iron banding came back.   37:34 The Supercontinent Columbia forms, it is about the size of Pangea and will be drifting around for 600 million years. The boring billion starts, nothing really happens, but the neighbouring planet, Venus, gets hotter and is struggling to keep habitable.     Columbia 43:50  breaks apart in the middle of the Ectasian. It now is becoming a new supercontinent soonâ€¦ What it is now is a continent appearing at both sides of the planet.      47:32  The Boring Billion ends, with life getting more fun and exciting.    Earth becomes now the only planet that is habitable now. 50:54 It is going to face a huge snowball event.  52:39 Life becomes better, with visible life appearing, which is the Phanerozoic.    The Cambrian starts. 53:54    54:51 Earth becomes greener. Pangea starts getting assembled around here.  56:23 The Carboniferous is a period where theres a lot of carbon. Thre isnt much to say but Pangea gets assembled.   57:22 The Great Dying appears, killing species on earth. Pangea is now here and dinosaurs appear.    57:43 Pangea starts breaking apart. Eurasia breaks apart from it.    58:17 The Jurassic is the most famous of all dinosaur ages. It is the golden age of Earth.   59:48 The KT Extinction happens, wiping out all dinosaurs. When it hit, nobody noticed until it rained molten glass and c02 filled the sky blocking out sunlight. It was hell, herbivoric dinosaurs was left with little to no food because it was a horrible winter. The herbivoric dinosaurs has no choice but to eat the dead bodies of other dinosaurs. Turning them to carnivores. After the dead bodies were gone, the herbivores died soon. But after that, earth recovered.   60:00 The Hour Mark. 55:48 59:43 1:00:43
Physical conditions (heat, atmosphere, radiation) are ignored.  The chemical stages of "life" (RNA, protein, lipid formation, etc.) are omitted.  And most importantly, the origin of life is told as a "story" but lacks a scientific basis.
Yes, the early Earth was largely covered with water, but the composition of this water was salty, acidic, and rich in minerals. It is biochemically impossible for life to have arisen directly from "rain-blown cells" in this environment. Evet, erken DÃ¼nya bÃ¼yÃ¼k oranda suyla kaplÄ±ydÄ± ama bu suyun bileÅŸimi tuzlu, asidik ve minerallerce yoÄŸundu. Bu ortamda yaÅŸamÄ±n doÄŸrudan â€œyaÄŸmurla gelen hÃ¼crelerdenâ€ tÃ¼remesi biyokimyasal olarak imkÃ¢nsÄ±z.
The statement "The temperature was over 40Â°C, covered with water"  This is also inconsistent:  In the early Earth (4 billion years ago), the surface temperature was close to 100Â°C, or even higher.  At that time, the oceans were not fully stable; they were constantly evaporating and condensing.  A "mild" temperature of 40Â°C belongs to the "cooling period" (approximately 3.5 billion years ago), when life would emerge much later.  Therefore, "40 degrees and the rain of cells" cannot have occurred during the same period.
This narrative is based on the so-called "panspermia theory" (the idea that life came from space).  But there are two major scientific problems here:  Cells are living structures. In space, with its high radiation, cold temperatures near absolute zero, and vacuum, it is impossible for living cells to survive intact.  If cells had descended to Earth "like rain," it would have been nearly impossible for them to do so without burning or disintegrating upon atmospheric re-entry. Even the majority of meteorites burn.  In other words, this narrative ignores biological, physical, and thermodynamic realities.
This video is like a story about a formation. It says that cells began to rain down on the earth, a sign of life. The cell itself is a living being. If we can't ask questions about the nature of this life form, how it came into being, and from what source it rained, like rain, then we're still talking about mindless creatures that remain cellular in size. The story is beautiful, if you put reason aside. Considering this video as evidence for atheism is a sign of a lack of logic, and so is the ignorance that the universe is pregnant with new formations every second.

The most important thing that is not even discussed by this video is that out of the 4.5 Billion years, no time has passed at all. You heard me right it is the same exact time now as it was 4.5 Billion years ago. That is simply due to the fact that time as we know it does not exist at all. Time is nothing more than a conceptual manmade tool that exists purely in the mind and not at all in reality. For time to exist there needs to be something called the Past the Present and the Future. The past only exists in the form of memories that is it. So the past only exists as a thought form and only when you are actively thinking about events based in a past. When you don't think about the past it ceases to exist. The future only exists as imagination and speculation. The present is the only thing that does exist as it is eternally Now. You can't escape Now to go to the past or future you are always experiencing things and events Now.

Wish he talked more about the Huronian Glaciation event. Since itâ€™s not that well known, we donâ€™t know whether it was a bunch of little ice ages, or one massive freeze much like the later Snowball Earth events of the Cryogenian period. Itâ€™s possible that there couldâ€™ve simply been massive ice sheets and icebergs all the way down to the equator, or that the entire planet wouldâ€™ve resembled Hoth. Also the Great Oxygenation Event was among the first mass extinction events as well, since oxygen back then was a poison to most forms of life (including the Cyanobacteria which had no immunity to their byproducts) it killed en masse. This oxygen also broke down methane in the atmosphere, severely degrading most greenhouse gases and ultimately causing the Huronian Glaciation event.

Since necessarily the closer one gets to the present, the more things have survived from the past, any sufficiently long history necessarily requires changing time scales at certain points, otherwise you will have long periods where nothing interesting happens, and short periods where too much happens too quickly to follow. So, the typical way a video about a long history would be structured would be to change time scales at certain intervals to keep the level of detail consistent throughout.  The disadvantage of doing so however is that it becomes difficult to conceptualize how much time is passing when the scales keep changing, and things happening at different time scales get lost. By keeping one consistent timescale for the entire video, this demonstrates what is happening at a geological timescale even as things happen on shorter timescales. What was particularly interesting here is it allowed the video to focus on things that would otherwise be missed, in this case in particular what happened to the Earth between its formation 4.5 billion years ago and the Cambrian explosion 538 million years ago. This time period would otherwise be largely ignored or skimmed over in most histories.  I'm sure this was a difficult video to make and took a lot of time and resources, and I think it was mainly created to make that point. But even so, I do wish Kurzgesagt would do a follow up video, as there are sorter timescales that I think would also benefit from the same treatment.  I would love to see a one hour video starting with more recent events: *The Cambrian explosion 538 million years ago *The Cretaceousâ€“Paleogene extinction event 66 million years ago *The split of the Australopithecus genus 4.2 million years ago *The first anatomically modern human 315,000 years ago *Origins of agriculture in West Asia 10,000 BCE *Printing of the Gutenberg Bible in 1450 CE  Recently I've been particularly curious why when anatomically modern humans first evolved 315,000 years ago, what further advancements were required before the Neolithic Revolution could actually begin.

"Life uh, finds a way" ;) Thanks for the great video
The concept behind this video is truly great. I actually came across it while researching for something similar, only to realize that a video closely aligned with my vision has already been made! However, when I saw the credits rolling with 40-50 names at the end, I thought to myself, "Wow, good thing I didn't attempt this solo."  After watching it a few more times, I couldn't help but feel that, with the resources this channel has, I might have produced an even better version. Itâ€™s impressive how such a great idea could still end up missing the mark, despite having a team of 40-50 creators. I hope this doesnâ€™t come across as arrogant, but hereâ€™s what I mean:  The visuals meant to symbolize the different epochs feel static, almost like a looping gif. I understand that you're trying to convey the vast passage of time, where each second represents millions of years, and that symbolizing this is no easy task. However, instead of capturing the most pivotal events of each epoch, weâ€™re mostly shown mountains and landscapes, which, while signifying time passing, donâ€™t communicate much else. For instance, you mention the famous asteroid impact during the Orosirian period, yet thereâ€™s no mention or visualization of its crater or even a proper depiction of the event. Additionally, the timing of these events doesn't seem to align with your timeline.  The monotonous landscapes really fail to engage the viewer. Weâ€™re talking about millions of years where continents collided, life emerged, and entire species came and went, but all weâ€™re seeing is mountains and hills. With the number of illustrators involved in this project, I expected a much richer visual experience.  Another aspect that didnâ€™t sit well with me was the music. It felt like a soundtrack for an intense, psychedelic trip, which, while it might be attempting to convey the earthâ€™s dynamism, was frequently interrupted by inconsistent voiceovers that broke the immersion. I assume the intention was to keep the audience engaged, but these surface-level remarks only served to distract from the flow.  The transitions between eras were also far too vague. When scientists define eras and mark the transitions between them, itâ€™s usually because significant events define those moments. Aside from the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs, the video barely touches on any other critical transitions. For example, the Great Oxidation Event should mark the end of the Rhyacian era, but we see nothing of it hereâ€”just more mountains and trap music.  I also found the depiction of life through the ages lacking. We barely see any life forms until the dinosaurs, which is a missed opportunity. Surely, it wasnâ€™t too difficult to illustrate the fascinating range of organisms that existed before then?  Finally, the depiction of the present era, arguably the most powerful part of the video, does manage to convey the awe-inspiring brevity of human existence in the grand timeline. But, just as you start to delve into this fascinating topic, the video quickly shifts into a fundraising plea. Given the unnecessary length of the introduction, it feels like more time should have been spent exploring the incredible story of early humans rather than cutting it short.  All that being said, I do respect the effort that went into this. However, considering the size of the team and the resources involved, this could have been achieved with far fewer people. It feels like the production costs werenâ€™t justified by the final product.

It's fascinating how quickly life itself developed, but then went on to take billions of years to become complex life.   As the sun ages it heats and thus complex life on Earth is on a time limit. Despite Earth being billions of years old, the window which complex life could exist may be ending within the next few hundred million years. If any bit of Earth's history was very slightly different complex life would have never come to exist, or ended in the cambrian or something.   I kinda wonder if simple life also 'normally' takes billions of years to evolve, but Earth was incredibly lucky in having this event happen early thus allowing enough time for complex life to arise. An event that takes a trillion years to happen on a planet is going to happen about once a year with a trillion planets.  If simple life takes a trillion years to evolve, and complex life takes a trillion years to evolve ... there will be a few planets that see complex life in a few billion years in this universe

The transcript of the video is quite comprehensive and seems mostly accurate regarding the sequence of Earth's history and the major events that have occurred over billions of years. However, there are a few areas where additional clarification or minor corrections could be useful:  1. Clarification of Terminology and Events: "The Great Oxidation Event" (27:52): This event indeed led to a significant increase in atmospheric oxygen, which fundamentally changed Earth's atmosphere and enabled the evolution of more complex life forms. It is worth noting, however, that oxygen levels fluctuated significantly after this event and did not reach levels suitable for complex multicellular life until much later. "And a natural, self-sustaining nuclear reactor awakes, just from scattered uranium deposits in the ground" (37:06): This refers to the natural nuclear fission reactors at Oklo in Gabon, which occurred about 1.7 billion years ago, not 1.8 billion years ago. It would be beneficial to clarify that this was a specific and unique geological occurrence rather than a widespread phenomenon on Earth. 2. Consistency in Naming Geological Periods and Events: The script jumps between using eons, eras, periods, and events without always making clear the distinctions or reasons for focusing on certain timeframes. For example: "Cambrian explosion" (53:35): This is well known as a period of rapid evolutionary diversification approximately 539 million years ago. However, it would be helpful to clarify that this marks the beginning of the Phanerozoic Eon and the Paleozoic Era, not just a specific "explosion" event. "Cryogenian" (51:14): This period is known for its "Snowball Earth" hypothesis, where the planet was covered in ice. However, stating "Earth freezes over again" might suggest this is a recurring event, whereas the Cryogenian glaciations are believed to have been particularly extreme and possibly unique in their extent. 3. Minor Errors or Potential Misinterpretations: "Right after it was born, Earth was a hell of lava..." (0:33): This description is accurate for the Hadean Eon, but it should be clarified that this period also involved heavy bombardment from space debris, which significantly shaped Earth's early surface and atmosphere. "4.5 Billion Years Ago we are in the first eon of our planet, the Hadean, named after the greek god of the underworld" (1:06): While correct, it's important to note that the term "Hadean" reflects not just the "underworld" aspect but also the chaotic and hellish conditions of early Earth. "1 Billion Years Ago the Tonian begins, another age where Earth is rocks and puddles and oceans" (47:33): This description might oversimplify the Tonian period, which is also noted for significant tectonic and geological activity, including the breakup of supercontinents. 4. Modern Context and Explanations: The script mentions, "Earth gets more and more familiar" during the Cretaceous (59:20), but this could be misleading since much of Earth's current geography and biota differ significantly from that time. It would be more precise to state that the planet's continents were beginning to assume positions more similar to todayâ€™s configuration. 5. Omissions or Missed Nuances: There is no mention of key evolutionary developments in the Ediacaran period (52:19), such as the emergence of complex multicellular life forms. While these are briefly alluded to ("Suddenly life gets big!"), further elaboration would help viewers understand the significance of this period in evolutionary history. 6. Typographical Errors and Style: Some parts of the text, such as "We get trees and forrests" (55:45), have minor typographical errors ("forests" should be "forests"). The narrative style switches between informal and scientific tones. Consistency in style could help maintain a more uniform presentation. Overall, the transcript is well-structured for a lay audience and accurately represents major milestones in Earth's history. Thinking about what life looked like during the Cambrian has lead me to a realization: SHUCKLE IS OLDER THAN RELICANTH.  "...dude, what? How are you getting that? You're talking about POKEMON?!?!?"  Yeah. Anomolocaris (Anorith and Armaldo) are from the Cambrian, meaning the other GenIII fossils, Lileep and Cradily,  are from the same time.   From there it's easy to see a connection between Lileep, Cradily and Shuckle.   Shuckle could have existed as early as 520 million years ago... TWO HUNDRED TWENTY MILLION YEARS BEFORE RELICANTH.

If 1.5 million (1,500,000) years pass every second in this hour, then every time you blink (which lasts ~100 milliseconds or a tenth of a second), 150,000 years pass. More than 10 times the length of recorded history goes by every time you blink in this video.

I'm sure someone else has brought it up but the idea that life 'might have' started at hydrothermal vents is generally *not* accepted as a potentiality. There are several stages from 'primordial soup' to 'single-celled life' that would require the interaction of UV light that couldn't physically be present at the hydrothermal vents.

0:00 Earth is 4.5 billion years old, impossible for your brain to truly grasp. So hereâ€™s an experiment. Every second around 1.5 million years will pass. Youâ€™re on a musical train ride looking out the window passing all of earth history in an hour. Watch as the eons pass, and experience how long s billion years really is. You can have this in the background, study with it, or just enjoy the ride. From time to time, Iâ€™ll say a few words. 4.5 billion years ago, right after it was born, earth was a hell of lava. Pretty early in its history, earth collides with a mars sized object called Thea which forms the moon that you now see in the sky. Right now it looks huge in the night sky and will slowly shrink over hundreds of millions of years as it orbits further away.   1:07 (4,529 mya) 4.5 billion years ago, we are in the first eon of our planet, the Hadean, named after the Greek God of the underworld.   1:32 (4,496 mya) at this point, the atmosphere is mostly CO2 and the floor is lava. This area of earthâ€™s history is mostly invisible to us because almost none of it is left.  2:06 (4,453 mya) 19 million years have passed. We are still in the lava hell phase. Settle in, this will take a while.  2:48 (4,400 mya) although you wouldnâ€™t think it, we found minerals called zircons that indicate there may have been some water around at this time.   6:48 (4,095 mya) during this period of the young solar system, earth and the inner solar system are smashed by a constant heavy asteroid bombardment for several hundred million years.  7:13 (4,065 mya) at this point in time, our sun is 30% less bright than it is today, but there are so many greenhouse gases that itâ€™s still much hot and comfy.   8:16 (3,984 mya) around this time we think life begins to enter the stage. Only a few hundred million years after the beginning of everything, the first cells begin spreading over our still very deadly planet.  8:37 (3,957 mya) earth continues to cool, and it probably rains for millions of years as our oceans begin to form covering the still young planet with water.   12:44 (3,645 mya) these hydrothermal vents weâ€™re looking at and where hot minerals emerge, may have been the place where life first developed, but we donâ€™t know.   13:19 (3,600 mya) so much time has passed and weâ€™re entering the  paleoarchean. Most of earth is still underwater, while the first supercontinents are in the making in the depths below. Its days are shorter since the young earth spins faster.   13:43 (3,569 mya) good job if youâ€™re still watching, youâ€™ve witnessed a billion years so far.   17:50 (3,256 mya) from this time in history, we still have stromatolites, sedimentary rocks built by microorganisms, among our first real evidence of life on earth. Also life is starting to eat the sun. Photosynthesis might have started as early as around here.   18:36 (3,200 mya) 3.2 billion years ago in the mesoarchean, the era of continents begins. Tectonic plates begin to crush into eachother, pulling and pushing some deep into the earth where they dissolve. The basis for our continents today. The oceans are as hot as a hot tub. Over 40Â° Celsius and microbes are expanding everywhere. We donâ€™t have plants yet to consume greenhouse gases so it it really really hot. You would basically die immediately in this atmosphere. Also thereâ€™s no oxygen in the atmosphere yet.   23:51 (2,800 mya) 2.8 billion years ago, the neoarchean begins. Earth is still a terribly hostile place but because we finally have proper plate tectonics, more chemicals are mixed from inside the earth, and life can use them to make new things.  24:35 (2,743 mya) some time around here prokaryotes like bacteria begin colonising the planet. Life diversifies more and more. But still after so much time, we only have single cells.  27:46 (2,500 mya) 2.5 billion years ago in the siderian, a massive event is about to begin that will change the planet forever: The Great Oxidation Event. Oxygen burped out by Cyanobacteria reaches the atmosphere in large quantities, paving the way for more complex life.   29:39 (2,358 mya) all the new oxygen in the air reacts with methane and forms CO2 and water, which rapidly cools the planet down.  30:16 (2,311 mya) probably for the first time ever, the planet freezes over and a period of multiple ice ages begins lasting millions of years.  30:27 (2,300 mya) 2.3 billion years ago the Rhyacian begins.  31:14 (2,237 mya) lots of volcanoes heat up earth and earth unfreezes slowly again. Melting ice flushes toxic elements into the oceans but life quietly puts up resistance and keeps evolving.  33:48 (2,042 mya) some time 2.05 billion years ago in the Orosirian a large asteroid hits Earth and creates the largest verified impact structure on earth.  34:47 (1,968 mya) all over earth great mountain ranges are crushed into existence by early continents with wild names like Ur, Nena or AtlÃ¢ntica.   37:00 (1,800 mya) 1.8 billion years ago in the statherian the supercontinent Columbia has formed. And a natural, self sustaining nuclear reactor awakes, just from scattered uranium deposits in the ground.  39:37 (1,600 mya) 1.6 billion years ago, around the edge of Calimmian, + or - a few hundred million years or so, the first eukaryotic cells, cells with a nucleus, merge from two other cells. One of the most important moments in the history of life. But yes, kind of looks not that impressive. Still, life is only cells.  41:35 (1,450 mya) earths crust thickens and heavy continents form, the oceans become shallower. Also the first fungi-like organisms extend their tubular arms and do fungi things.  42:17 (1,400 mya) some time in the Ectasian 1.4 billion years ago, earths inner core is forming. Weird, right? Feels like it should be older. But around here it begins to solidify into an iron crystal surrounded by hot Liquid Metal. It will only grow from now on.   44:54 (1,200 mya) 1.2 billion years ago in the stenian not that much is going on. Except, the algae Bangiomorpha pubescens might have invented s**. A big reproductive improvement for many different reasons.   47:34 (1,000 mya) 1 billion years ago the Tonian begins, another age where earth is rocks puddles and oceans. Life is still invisible to the naked eye. It does feel different to witness it like that, right?  50:08 (800 mya) not everybody is having a great time here. We have evidence that the first unicellular predators emerging around that time. The dominance of bacteria and big boy eukaryotes plant their flags in the oceans. An arms race between microbes that again creates huge diversity. Some even invent tiny armour.   51:15 (720 mya) 720 million years ago in the Cryogenian earth freezes over again. Sure why not. How did life survive? Weâ€™re not sure.  52:18 (635 mya) 635 million years ago the supercontinent Gondwana forms. A lot of it is still left today!   53:15 Wow! Whatâ€™s happening? Suddenly life gets big. In a hot second multicellular organisms become widespread! Itâ€™s all strange aliens still, but can you imagine that it took that long for this to happen?   53:36 (539 mya) 539 million years ago the Cambrian explosion begins. We see life bursting with variety. Ancestors of almost all of todayâ€™s major animal groups appear here while the plants start to discover the land. Life is finally exciting. But of course a big mass extinction happens right after, killing most species in the ocean.  55:00 (430 mya) plants spread over the planet and create the soil on the ground and change the atmosphere by eating CO2.  55:39 (381 mya) things escalate. Flora and fauna adapt better to life on land. We get trees and forests, fish and the first vertibrate decide this land thing is something they need to try out!  55:56 (359 mya) 359 million years ago in the Carboniferous forests and lush marshlands are at their peak. They will turn into the coal humanity burns today to keep ourselves warm. Itâ€™s all so fast now! Life changes so quickly in geological timeframes!  56:43 (300 mya) some 299 million years ago in the Permian, Pangea the last supercontinent has formed. And after a few tens of millions years, the largest mass extinction in history happens, killing the majority of all species. Thanks volcanoes.   57:23 (252 mya) 252 million years ago the Triassic begins.   57:41 (227 mya) oh hey, a dinosaur!  58:03 (201 mya) we are now truly in the age of reptiles. Dinosaurs are everywhere! The ancestors of the birds do bird things. Life, uhh, finds a way!  59:21 (100 mya) earth gets more and more familiar.   59:38 (78 mya) such a paridise. Life is thriving. Nothing can go wrongâ€¦ wait, whatâ€™s that?   59:50 (66 mya) and an asteroid killed the dinosaurs and most species on earth. Such a bummer.   59:57 (54 mya) 66 million years ago in the paleogene the continents look roughly the same as today and mammals take over. It is our time now! We are almost home.  1:00:39 (2,600 years ago) Donâ€™t blink or you might miss all of human history!  1:00:45 and at was it. Earth is ancient. We are new. So new. This was a project born of passion. Weâ€™ve worked on this video on and off since 2019 and as you can imagine, it took forever to make. But we did finish it in time for our tenth anniversary. If you want to support experimental videos like this one please like, share and subscribe and press the bell. You can also continue your journey through time with our new timeline of evolution poster. Discover how long it took for the first cellular blobs to evolve into fishes, then dinosaurs, and finally into mammals- and encounter creatures youâ€™ve never heard of along the way. This poster is part of our education edition. A poster series that brings complex topics to life through extensive research and elaborate illustrations. Itâ€™s perfect for teachers, students, and science lovers. Get them from our shop and support what we do on this channel. In any case if you got this far, thank you so much! Hope you felt something watching this.

It's actually quite wild that the Christian's Bible record of the creation of earth in genesis 1 is quite accurate if you interpret the "days" as "timelines". First it was the creation of the earth(which lacked form and void) and then darkness (the Sun was not as bright as it was today). Then the appearance of water and then land. If you read verses 20 and 21, you would see how it was described that life was indeed "brought forth from the waters". Plants and herbs came into the picture first, and then the creation of every other being, with the creation of Man being last. I just find it uncanny and bewildering for these timelines to be scientifically accurate.

This video got me wondering about how multicellularity arose from unicellularity, and the imagery of all the rain made me ponder if multicellularity arose as some sort of adaptation to resist being carried away by precipitation and dying on land. Unicellular life near the surface of the primordial oceans might have been carried up by evaporation and rained onto land where it would die. Microbes that happened to be bound together in some way might have been heavy enough to resist being evaporated and over millions of years and various other factors maybe this led to multicellularity. The End of the Hadean Age  Starting the age of Eoarchean  Eoarchean was not a hell hole, but there was rocks filled with lava, But rain started and clearing the lava rocks and turning them to obsidan.   The End of the Eoarchean age.  Entering Paleoarchean Age.  Paleoarchean age had Earth under water, Earth in the Paleoarchean age was just water, No ground, no human but there is some fish.  Paleoarchean Age left.  Mesoarchean Age Joined.  Mesoarchean age have now grounds, but they're weren't just normal land, they were continents, Water and Ground now formed in Earth  The End of the Mesoarchean Age.  Entering Neoarchean Age.  Now when going to the ocean, it's deep, close and shallow parts, When Theia crashed into earth, they formed the Moon (Luna) so that means tides have formed.  The End of the Neoarchean Age.  Entering the Siderian Age.  Siderian age had Oxygen (o2) and almost Earth can almost support life.  Entering the Rhyacian Age  The Earth is freezing to death because of the Rhyacian age, But volcanoes can keep the Earth warm to prevent global warming. So, if we are to extract a lesson from this video, is that single-cell life might be abundant and not a difficult development in a planet with the right conditions. Multicellular life, on the other hand, took about 3.5 billion~ years to develop, which may be one of the reasons we haven't spotted any other life forms close by. For all we know, they could still be in their pre-multicellular life stages, and we have no way to detect them or knowing if they ever got past that stage (mass extinctions are quite the thing, apparently).

I'm in absolute awe that the planet knew how to change periods so swiftly as though someone said, it's time now - change it up. Life is a miracle.
Every single SECOND in this video is about a million years. More than the entire lifetime of our species. Think about that. All those billions of years where so little happened could have encapsulated our entire history, thousands of times over.  The other thing I wonder is: how many times could life have reached a stasis point beyond which there would be no pressure to evolve further. Think about it - without the additional nutrients provided by plate tectonics, it would have stayed as archaea on the ocean floor. Without the ozone created by photosynthesis that created a shield from the deadly lazer of UV, it would have had little chance on land. It's so hard to think about alternative paths because we have a grand sample size of ONE for life in the universe so far. But the fact that all these things had to come together, and that it took so long just to get to multicellular life, to me implies that there are relatively few worlds that are as bucolic as this in our universe. Many places have microbes; perhaps EVERY place where it can happen, that at least does. But our macroscopic, stupendously complex multicellular biosphere may be an exceedingly rare oasis in a desert of a galaxy. Let alone any individual species coming out of that who MIGHT, SOMEHOW make a technological civilization that won't destroy itself, and be visible from interstellar distances.  Odds are, no one will ever know we were here.
This is not just a very educational, and nicely animated video. It will be my favorite videoclip from now on. What the Kurzgesagt team did here is ART. Pure art. Thanks for your 10 years of work, and I wish you a few more billions of years like those!

Awesome overview! This is great, but...  I love it that secular scientists use the argon dating method and make a guess about the initial amount of argon and use that as a basis for dating rocks and then publish the data using the accuracy of the measuring device to say how accurate it is and then make up some narrative to fit the dating. To properly use the argon dating method you have to know the initial amount of argon in the rock samples and this is hard to do unless you can travel back in time at which point you already know the amount of time it took anyways. Just look at the rock samples from Mount St. Helens that exploded in the 80:s. A geologist (forgot his name) published a paper where he sent three samples from the same piece of volcanic material to be dated. They varied from ~100 ky, ~380 ky and ~2.2 My IIRC. That's how accurate it is. The argon dating method is one of the methods of dating the Earth.  So it can be said that this is the history of the world according to the world. :)

holyyyy! This is so absolutely awesome!!
We tend to think about life becoming more complex as an inherent direction of evolution (antropocentric thinking). But looking at the actual events this isn't the case at all. Greater complexity always have arisen due to mere chance - like the emerge of cooperative cells in the form of Eukaryotes in the Statherian - or due to compulsion - like the emerge of regulated cooperation which gave rise to body tissues in the Ediacaran.  I know this is speculation but still i'm fairly certain regulated cooperation gave a significant edge to the cells inventing it during the Sturtian snowball Earth when life has survived in heavily restricted safe haven areas like around geysers. Having this ability made them much more effective in utilizing the severely limited living space compared to non-regulated cells and cell groups. This ultimately gave rise to body tissues which then proliferated in the restored living spaces of the Ediacaran and became large in size for the Cambrian. So animals with body tissues - which we consider standard today - emerged probably only due to compulsion from an extremely harsh environment.
the composition of earth and it's process to become life itself make me believe there is a creator behind..

Nice video for getting a different sense of scale. How 'fast' things evolved in the last 600 million years or so  (even though a long time in itself)  compared to the geological stretches of time before that, before evolution seemed to kick into higher gear. Also, to realise that even that very last second depicting a human is still 1.5 million years, and that what we usually think of as our 'long'  human history since the invention of writing would only last about 0.0036 seconds in this video (about 5400 years since the oldest Sumerian writings). So even only considerig that single second of human existence, we know very little of the first 'prehistoric' 0.9964 second part.

INTRO Â  0:00 Earth is 4.5 billion years old - impossible for your brain to truly grasp, so here is an experiment: Â  0:08 every second around 1.5 million years will pass - you're on a musical train ride Â  0:14 looking out the window, passing all of Earth's History in an hour. Watch the eons pass and experience how long a billion years really is. Â  0:25 You can have this in the background, study with it or just enjoy the ride. From time to time, I'll say a few words. Â  0:33  4.5 billion years ago, right after it was born, Earth was a hell of lava... Â  0:41  Pretty early in its history, Earth collides with a Mars sized object called Theia, Â  0:47  which forms the moon that you now see in the sky. Â  HADEAN Â  0:53 Right now it looks huge in the night sky and will slowly shrink over hundreds of millions Â  0:59  of years as it orbits further away. Â  1:06  4.5 Billion Years Ago we are in the first eon of our planet, the Hadean, named after the greek god of the underworld. Â  1:32 At this point the Atmosphere is mostly CO2 and the floor is lava. Â  1:39  This area of earth's history is mostly invisible to us because almost none of it is left. Â  2:06  90 million years have passed. We are still in the lava hell phase. Â  2:11  Settle in, this will take a while. Â  2:47  Although you wouldn't think it, we found minerals called zircons that indicate Â  2:52  there may have been some water around at this time. Â  6:48  During this period of the young solar system, Earth and the inner solar system are smashed by a constant heavy asteroid bombardment, for several hundred million years. Â  7:12  At this point in time, our Sun is 30% less bright than it is today but there are so many Â  7:19  greenhouse gases that it's still much hot and comfy. Â  EOARCHEAN Â  8:16 Around this time we think life begins to enter the stage. Â  8:21 Only a few hundred million years after the beginning of everything the first cells begin Â  8:27 spreading over our still very deadly planet. Â  8:37 Earth continues to cool and it probably rains for millions of years as our oceans begin to form, covering the still young planet with water. Â  12:43 These hydrothermal vents we're looking at, and where hot minerals emerge, may have been Â  12:49 the place where life first developed, but we don't know. Â  13:18 So much time has passed and we are entering the Paleoarchean. Paleoarchean Â  13:23 Most of Earth is still underwater while the first supercontinents are in the making Â  13:29 in the depths below. Its days are shorter since the young Earth spins faster. Â  13:42 Good job if you are still watching. You've witnessed a billion years so far. Â  17:49 From this time in history we still have Stromatolites, sedimentary rocks built by microorganisms. Â  17:56 Among our first real evidence of life on Earth. Also life is starting to eat the sun - photosynthesis might have started as early as around here. Â  MESOARCHEAN Â  18:35 3.2 Billion Years Ago in the Mesoarchean the era of continents begins. Â  18:42 Tectonic plates begin to crush into each other, pulling and pushing some deep into the earth Â  18:48 where they dissolve. The basis for our continents today. Â  18:54 The oceans are as hot as a hot tub, over 40Â°C and microbes are expanding everywhere. Â  19:03 We don't have plants yet to consume greenhouse gases, so it is really, really hot. Â  19:10 You would basically die immediately in this atmosphere. Also there is no oxygen in the atmosphere yet. Â  NEOARCHEAN Â  23:51 2.8 Billion Years Ago the Neoarchean begins. Earth is still a terribly hostile place but because we finally have proper plate tectonics, Â  24:02 more chemicals are mixed in from inside the earth and life can use them to make new things! Â  24:34 Some time around here Prokaryotes like bacteria begin colonizing the planet. Â  24:40 Life diversifies more and more. But still, after so much time, we only have single cells. Â  27:46 2.5 Billion Years Ago in the Siderian, a massive event is about to begin Â  SIDERIAN Â  27:52 that will change the planet forever: The Great Oxidation Event. Â  27:57 Oxygen, burped out by cyanobacteria reaches the atmosphere in large quantities, Â  28:03 paving the way for more complex life. Â  29:39 All the new oxygen in the air reacts with methane and forms CO2 and Water, Â  29:44 which rapidly cools the planet down. Â  30:16 Probably for the first time ever, the planet freezes over and a period of multiple Â  30:21 ice ages begin lasting millions of years. Â  RHYACIAN Â  30:27 2.3 Billion Years Ago the Rhyacian begins. Â  31:14  Lots of volcanoes heat up earth and earth unfreezes slowly again. Â  31:20 Melting ice flushes toxic elements into the oceans but life quietly puts up resistance Â  31:27  and keeps evolving. Â  ORISIRIAN Â  33:48 Some time 2.05 Billion Years Ago in the Orosirian a large asteroid hits earth and creates the Â  33:56 largest verified impact structure on Earth. Â  34:47 All over Earth great mountain ranges are crushed into existence by early continents Â  34:52 with wild names like Ur, Nena or Atlantica. Â  STATHERIAN  Â  37:00 1.8 Billion Years Ago in the Statherian the supercontinent Columbia has formed. Â  37:06 And a natural, self sustaining nuclear reactor awakes, just from scattered uranium deposits in the ground. Â  39:37 1.6 billion years ago, around the edge of Calimmian, + or - a few hundred million years or so, Â  CALYMMIAN  Â  39:44 the first Eukaryotic cells, cells with a nucleus, merge from two other cells. Â  39:50 One of the most important moments in the history of life. But yes, kind of looks not that impressive. Â  39:59 Still, life is only cells. Â  41:35 Earth's crust thickens and heavy continents form, the oceans become shallower. Â  41:42 Also the first fungi-like organisms extent their tubular arms and do fungi things. Â  ECTASIAN  Â  42:17 Some time in the Ectasian 1.4 Billion Years Ago, Earths inner core is forming. Â  42:24 Weird, right? Feels like it should be older. But around here it begins to solidify into a iron crystal surrounded by hot liquid metal. Â  42:34 It will only grow from now on. Â  STENIAN  Â  44:53 1.2 Billion Years Ago in the Stenian not that much is going on. Â  44:59 Except, the algae Bangiomorpha pubescens might have invented sex. Â  45:05 A big reproductive improvement for many different reasons. Â  TONIAN Â  47:33 1 Billion Years Ago the Tonian begins, another age where Earth is rocks and puddles and oceans. Â  47:42 Life is still invisible to the naked eye. It does feel different to witness it like that, right? Â  50:07 Not everybody is having a great time here. We have evidence of the first unicellular predators emerging around that time. Â  50:16 The dominance of bacteria ends and big boy eukaryotes plant their flags in the oceans. An arms race between microbes begins that again creates huge diversity. Â  50:29 Some even invent tiny armour. Â  CRYOGENIAN  Â  51:14 720 Million Years Ago in the Cryogenian Earth freezes over again. Â  51:21 Sure why not. How did life survive? We are not sure. Â  EDIACARAN  Â  52:19 635 Million Years Ago the supercontinent Gondwana forms. Â  52:24 A lot of it is still left today! Â  53:15 Wow! What's happening? Suddenly life gets big! In a hot second multicellular organisms become widespread! Â  53:24 It's all strange aliens still, but can you imagine that it took that long for this to happen? Â  CAMBRIAN  Â  53:35 539 Million Years Ago the Cambrian explosion begins. Â  53:40 We see life bursting with variety. Ancestors of almost all of today's major animal groups appear here while the plants start Â  53:49 to discover the land. Life is finally exciting! Â  53:54 But of course a big mass extinction happens right after, killing most species in the ocean. Â  SILURIAN  Â  55:01 Plants spread over the planet and create the soil on the ground and change the atmosphere Â  55:07 by eating CO2. Â  DEVONIAN  Â  55:38 Things escalate. Flora and fauna adapt better and better to life on land. Â  55:45 We get trees and forrests, fish and the first vertebrate decide this land thing Â  55:51 is something they need to try out! Â  CARBONIFEROUS  Â  55:56 359 Million Years Ago in the Carboniferous forests and lush marshlands are at their peak. Â  56:05 They will turn into the coal humanity burns today to keep ourselves warm. Â  56:12 It's all so fast now! Life changes so quickly in geological timeframes! Â  56:42 Some 299 Million Years Ago in the Permian, Pangea, the last supercontinent has formed. Â  PERMIAN 56:50 And after a few tens of million years, the largest mass extinction in history happens, Â  56:56 killing the majority of all species. Thanks volcanoes. Â  TRIASSIC Â  57:23 252 Million Years Ago the Triassic begins. Â  57:41 Oh hey, a dinosaur! Â  JURASSIC  Â  58:02 We are now truly in the age of reptiles. Dinosaurs are everywhere! Â  58:08 The ancestors of the birds do bird things. Life, uhh, finds a way! Â  CRETACEOUS  Â  59:20 Earth gets more and more familiar. Â  59:38  Such a paradise. Life is thriving. Nothing can go wrong... wait, what's that? Â  PALEOGENE  Â  59:50 And an asteroid killed the dinosaurs and most species on Earth. Such a bummer. Â  59:57 66 Million Years Ago in the Paleogene the continents look roughly the same as today and mammals take over. Â  1:00:06 It is our time now! We are almost home. There's an error at 58:53 - the moon NEVER looks like that at night: The middle of the crescent indicates where the sun is, which would place the sun high in the sky, but the scene is night time. At night, the middle of the crescent must be on the low side of the moon.

Here's what I got:  4.5bn years : 1 hour 1 year = 24 x 365.2425 = 8765.82 hours 4.5bn years = 8764.82 * 450000000000 = 39446190000000 hours 39446190000000 hours = 142006284000000000 seconds  ratio 142006284000000000 : 3600 (seconds) (like units) simplifies to 39446190000000 : 1  so every (1) second represents (39446190000000) seconds  39446190000000 seconds = 10957275000 hours = 456553125 days = 1,250,000 years. Why not just bring it down to a nice round 1 million years per second?
Now, Every view in this video is 1,000 years of Earth. (well almost, 4.531B < 4.543B) edit: 4.574B > 4.543B, 43,000 views in 4 hours

One slight correction: current evidence suggests that the cooling of the surface and the formation of the first (global) ocean took about half as long as depicted here. The millions of years of rain was likely over by the latter half of the Hadean (4.2 Gya), thus allowing life to begin (the first fossils are from 3.7 Gya, but that likely does not represent the first life â€” some geochemical results suggest the existence of a carbon cycle around 4.1 Gya, which could possibly indicate the presence of life. I don't blame you for getting this wrong, though â€” it's fairly recent research and a lot of textbooks and educational sites have not updated their information. Also, it's incorrect to say that life was still invisible to the naked eye in the Tonian â€” stromatolites and other colonial organisms existed, obviously, but also small multicellular plants (red algae) were starting to arise during that time. Basically, just shift a lot of the early stuff slightly earlier : )

1:28 and I'm pausing to tell you, @kurzgesagt that this *is* going to be found, an incorrect view, of what the early Earth was like.  I'm just going to say it; we are, the core, of a dying, hot Jupiter.  Think about it long enough, and, all the signs you need, will come to you.  1. Stars form from, mostly, gas. 2. Planets form from what is left, still, mistly gas, in composition, just not proximity to their star. 3. Other planetary systems have hot jupiters in this zone, at the time we would have been in the Hadean, by comparisson. . . . Etc.etc.  (Battery is dying.)  I just want to say one more thing. I think the Sun had a small binary companion star, it ate it, eventually, and, not just photoevaporation blew our gasses (Mercury - Mars) to the asteroid belt and beyond, but, (lotta commas, I know) the blast, from the merger, violently, forced it off us   And only in the last, few, hundred million to a billion or so years, have we had much sunlight down here, for photosynthesis, let alone, continents that were not submerged in liquids and gasses of, significantly different ratios.  2% battery. Sending.

Cool addition to Great Oxydation event and all prior ages would be the importance of reductive-oxidative shift in the nature of our atmosphere. It was first reductive, so all oceans were essentially swarmed with iron and other metal ions. After oxygen had began to be produced, all those ions were starting to form ores. This is essentially the way ALL ORES on our planet were formed. Also, it's the reason why oxygen levels didn't suddenly rise up to 21%, but have been kept nearly 7% for a couple hundreds of millions of years.

This video should be required viewing as a part of every Historical Geology course in existence.  The immersiveness and real sense of the scale of earth history time, as well as the causes and effects of great changes - the great oxidation event, little issues like the advent of CO2 causing the earth to cool by decreasing the greenhouse gas methane, the catastrophic changes at extinction events, the ebb and flow of hospitability of the planet through such transitions as the snowball earth, and the relative wink of an eye during which multicellular life has existed bring perspective in the span of one lecture hour that many semester-long courses cannot - mired as they are in detail.  A wonderful and insightful undertaking - a time machine in which we can all ride.  Kudos to all involved in its creation.

This past fall, I have been taking a biology course in college and for those who don't know, the wonderful birbs of this channel were very freaking thorough in the making of this video. To see how the earliest protist developed towards becoming eukaryotes as some of the earliest protist, then getting the foreshadow of the soon-to-be rise of invertebrates as a moment was given to the earliest fungi (both invertebrates and fungi came about around the same time from the opisthokonta branch of unikonta protists), to then revealing so much more. Don't even get me started on the bryophytas towards the vascular monilophytas, and the earliest gymnosperm (coniferophyta) and angiosperms (those fancy-looking red flowers with what seemed to have had several stamens.) As insignificant as Kurzgesagt videos may make you feel, especially this one we've just all enjoyed together. I think this video also presents a perfect opportunity to recognize how even the smallest seemingly insignificant actions taken can have unimaginably profound effects when given the opportunity to amplify through equally unimaginable scales of time. Take that original single celled prokaryotic cell that decided randomly at one point, to take in another unimpressive cell but not eat it and instead form something of two cells. In the instant it happened and even for the millennias after it happened, we would not recognize any significant impacts it had on the planet; yet through the timescale of the Earth, that moment could not have been less integral to our existence today and the existence of everything around us. What you do on a day to day basis may feel tiny and unimportant in present, but who knows what chain of events may eventually occur originating from any of your accomplishments; be it a scientific discovery, or just putting your left shoe on first, your potential to influence the next 4.5 billion years will always be oppositely proportional to the certainty that you will do some seemingly insignificant things <3
Please make more of these to study to!

This needs to be shown to EVERYONE, absolutely everyone on the planet needs to see this, and if they're not immediately in love with our fragile blue jewel, well, perhaps their humanity should be questioned! LOL I kid, but not about the quality of this video. The only other piece that's made my soul and imagination soar, on the sheer quality and composition of the audio alone, was Ivan Torrent's Human Legacy. This absolute magnum opus is a treasure for the eyes, ears, and mind, but more importantly, it's a balm for one's SOUL. In a period where people are fired up, angrier than ever, and the world is groaning under all of that sadness and pain, You, Kurzgesagt, are always there with a dose of education, knowledge, and in this, you provide a unifying force that we so desperately need.  While watching this, especially as you began to uncover the later eras and epochs of our planet, suddenly I was transported back to 1998, when the PBS channel was the primary source of entertainment with shows like Kratt's Kreatures and Bill Nye the Science Guy, and the MECC edutainment games held the crown for scientific learning and education. I felt like I was suddenly roving the halls of Museum Madness again, uncovering the secrets of the universe and bringing dinosaurs back to life in the exhibits!  You folks have a storytelling GIFT, and I thank you for sharing it with us throughout the years.

Problems with the video: 1. Some eras should change gradually, not instantly poof into another at their end. For example, the Hadean should have a gradual lessening of the lava and meteors, not this instant change into the Eoarchean. Completely, absurdly unreal. 2. The Great Oxygen Event was fluffed over, when it was the worst mass extinction in earth's history. It should have been visible that almost all life died, and the entire planet changed color with precipitating oxides. 3. Dinosaurs aren't reptiles. "The Age of the Reptiles" is an outdated term that should have been replaced with "Age of the Dinosaurs".

Imagine if Earth's geologic history was a canvas, not just of rocks and fossils, but of stories waiting to be told. Each layer holds tales of dramatic transformations. What if, hidden in these layers, there are messages left by ancient, advanced civilizations that existed on Earth millions of years before humans? Civilizations that rose and fell, leaving barely a trace, now buried under eons of geological change.  What if these ancient inhabitants had their own versions of dinosaurs, their own catastrophic events, and their own leaps in evolution, but their stories were wiped clean by time, leaving us as the current narrators of Earth's saga? This thought experiment challenges our understanding of time, evolution, and the fragility of civilizations. It reminds us that we, too, are just a layer in Earth's grand narrative, and it's up to us to decide what story that layer tells. Will future geologists find our layer marked by innovation and stewardship, or by neglect and downfall?  As we visualize Earth's vast geologic history, let's not just look back in awe, but also forward with responsibility. After all, we're not just inhabitants of this planet; we're its storytellers.

One interesting thought is how civilization doesn't even represent a single frame in this video  Written language emerged only about 5,500 years ago, and in the video, each second represents 1.5 million years. At 30 frames per second, the era from the beginning of written language to today would last approximately 0.11 frames.  Another fascinating point: this video covers 4.5 billion years. Many scientists estimate that in about 1 to 1.5 billion years, the Sun's increasing brightness is expected to cause a runaway greenhouse effect on Earth, leading to conditions too hot for liquid water and life to exist.  So, if the video continued, this period would be represented by another 10-15 minutes.

I love Kurzgesagt. But gotta nitpick Kurzgesagt's thumbnail. The reason why the word "Pre-history" exists is because "history" begins with the written word. So there aren't 4.5 billion years of history. History began in about 3400 BC, only a few thousand years ago. Before that it was pre-history.

@SPCv4 an hour long animation takes  at most a few weeks to produce with a single skilled animator and modern animation software. Most of the time, animators just pick the beginning and end poses of a scene and a few intermediary steps then the computer interpolates between the positions to achieve the desired effect. This means it takes a few minutes to about an hour max to render a minute of animation. A really labor intensive portion of animation is lip flapping to speech track, but they don't have any of that in these videos, and there's also software that can do that automatically.

Neoarchean- The character managed to reestablish himself and do new things. Siderean- The character managed to recover even more and begins to survive in a pleasant way Rhyacian- The character loses past mistakes and creates a protective layer due to his traumas. Orosirian- Everything is going well for the main character who is already established Statherian- The character panics over past traumas Calyman- The main character resolves his traumas and appears the calm after the storm Ectasian- Your professional and social life has been restored Stenian- The character starts dating and doing lewd acts Tonian-Explosion in manipulative and toxic relationship Cryogenian- The character goes into depression or/and falls into drugs. Me and the boys watching the Hadean period
Subtitles from 30sec mark to 50min  00:00:33 4.5 billion years ago, right after it was born, Earth was a hell of lavaâ€¦  00:00:41 Pretty early in its history, Earth collides with a Mars sized object called Theia, which forms the moon that you now see in the sky. Right now it looks huge in the night sky and will slowly shrink over hundreds of millions of years as it orbits further away.  00:01:06 4.5 Billion Years Ago we are in the first eon of our planet, the Hadean, named after the greek god of the underworld.  00:01:32 At this point the Atmosphere is mostly CO2 and the floor is lava. This area of earth's history is mostly invisible to us because almost none of it is left.  00:02:06 90 million years have passed.  We are still in the lava hell phase. Settle in, this will take a while.  00:02:47 Although you wouldn't think it, we found minerals called zircons that indicate there may have been some water around at this time.  00:06:48 During this period of the young solar system, Earth and the inner solar system are smashed by a constant heavy asteroid bombardment, for several hundred million years.  00:07:12 At this point in time, our Sun is 30% less bright than it is today but there are so many greenhouse gases that it's still much hot and comfy.  00:08:16 Around this time we think life begins to enter the stage. Only a few hundred million years after the beginning of everything the first cells begin spreading over our still very deadly planet. Earth continues to cool and it probably rains for millions of years as our oceans begin to form, covering the still young planet with water.  00:12:43 These hydrothermal vents we're looking at, and where hot minerals emerge, may have been the place where life first developed, but we dont know.  00:13:18 So much time has passed and we are entering the Paleoarchean. Most of Earth is still underwater while the first supercontinents are in the making in the depths below. Its days are shorter since the young Earth spins faster. Good job if you are still watching. You witnessed a billion years so far.  00:17:49 From this time in history we still have Stromatolites, sedimentary rocks built by microorganisms. Among our first real evidence of life on Earth. Also life is starting to eat the sun â€“ photosynthesis might have started as early as around here.  00:18:35 3.2 Billion Years Ago in the Mesoarchean the era of continents begins. Tectonic plates begin to crush into each other, pulling and pushing some deep into the earth where they dissolve. The basis for our continents today. The oceans are as hot as a hottub, over 40Â°C and microbes are expanding everywhere. We don't have plants yet to consume greenhouse gases, so it is really, really hot. You would basically die immediately in this atmosphere. Also there is no oxygen in the atmosphere yet.  00:23:51 2.8 Billion Years Ago the Neoarchean begins. Earth is still a terribly hostile place but because we finally have proper plate tectonics, more chemicals are mixed in from inside the earth and life can use them to make new things!  00:24:34 Some time around here Prokaryotes like bacteria begin colonizing the planet. Life diversifies more and more. But still, after so much time, we only have single cells.  00:27:46 2.5 Billion Years Ago in the Siderian, a massive event is about to begin that will change the planet forever: The Great Oxidation Event. Oxygen, burped out by cyanobacteria reaches the atmosphere in large quantities, paving the way for more complex life.  00:29:39 All the new oxygen in the air reacts with methane and forms CO2 and Water, which rapidly cools the planet down.  00:30:16 Probably for the first time ever, the planet freezes over and a period of multiple ice ages begins lasting millions of years. 2.3 Billion Years Ago the Rhyacian begins.  00:31:14 Lots of volcanos heat up earth and earth unfreezes slowly again. Melting ice flushes toxic elements into the oceans but life quietly puts up resistance and keeps evolving.  00:33:49 Some time 2.05 Billion Years Ago in the Orosirian a large asteroid hits earth and creates the largest verified impact structure on Earth.  00:34:47 All over Earth great mountain ranges are crushed into existence by early continents with wild names like Ur, Nena or Atlantica.  00:37:00 1.8 Billion Years Ago in the Statherian the supercontinent Columbia has formed. And a natural, self sustaining nuclear reactor awakes, just from scattered uranium deposits in the ground.  00:39:37 1.6 billion years ago, around the edge of Calimmian, + or - a few hundred million years or so, the first Eukaryotic cells, cells with a nucleus, merge from two other cells. One of the most important moments in the history of life. But yes, kind of looks not that impressive. Still, life is only cells.  00:41:35 Earth's crust thickens and heavy continents form, the oceans become shallower. Also the first fungi-like organisms extent their tubular arms and do fungi things. Some time in the Ectasian 1.4 Billion Years Ago, Earths inner core is forming. Weird, right? Feels like it should be older. But around here it begins to solidify into a iron crystal surrounded by hot liquid metal. It will only grow from now on.  00:44:53 1.2 Billion Years Ago in the Stenian not that much is going on. Except, the algae Bangiomorpha pubescens might have invented sex. A big reproductive improvement for many different reasons.  00:47:33 1 Billion Years Ago the Tonian begins, another age where Earth is rocks and puddles and oceans. Life is still invisible to the naked eye. It does feel different to witness it like that, right?  00:50:07 Not everybody is having a great time here...

You see, this channel is my favorite channel currently subscribed to with my other accounts, so when I saw this video, I mean you guys really pushed it to a new level.  I have been since the age of 8, a fan of the french-belgian cartoon of "Il etait une fois l'homme" and this video reminds me of this.  It is a beautiful tapestry of the result of combining a modern Il etait une fois l'homme animation with a music dj set of 1 hour, presenting life and the history of.  I as a music producer from Canada, have really appreciate the detail of the score for this animation very much.  It feels like a long progressive EDM set by the Kurzgesagt DJ himself, hopefully Duck!  The music flows beautifully well with the visuals.  The details are amazing and worthy of reviewing many many times. This informative stellar artistry is captivating to say the least.  This is a grand production.  I love all of your videos very much and as the proud owner of some of your paraphernalia, I dig your product very much, but this episode is simply something at a new level.  This can absolutely stand by itself as a feature visual presentation in any planetarium on earth.  Even the Las Vegas Sphere should play this one time!  The only downfall, through no fault of your own, is the commercial adds breaks.  The swift scenery changes with the music adjustments is such a delight to experience I cannot get enough of it.  Now team Kurzgesagt, I believe this video will be quite  hard to top fellas, but I wish you the best of luck for the future.  Thank you from the bottom of my soul for producing such a gem.  Hats off to the animators and the music producers behind the score.

It's been a multi-decade challenge to create the machine taking you into the past. The oldest Lunar anorthosites are 4.4 Ga old. Yet, I am not seeing the formation of the anorthosite flotation crust on the Moon at this time. Instead, we see something slowly cooling over like 300 Ma. This is pretty inaccurate. A global anorthosite layer likely formed and cooled fairly rapidly. You might say, "Well, this video is on the Earth." To which I'd say, we don't have anything that old that paints a picture of the Earth, while we have a ton of information on the Moon, and arbitrarily sepating the Earth-Moon system does a disservice to its history.  You might also say something about the Late Heavy Bombardment, ~4.1-3.8 Ga. Now, you might dispute that it even happened; it might just be the tale-end of accretion, but a lot of ink has been spilled on this topic, so it deserves mention.  You should check out the papers on viscosity changes driven by Snowball Earth glaciation causing multicellularity to arise. "We're not sure" how life survived during the Cryogenian is not entirely accurate.  The "Cambrian Explosion" is a fossil horizon in which abundant fossils are concentrated. There is evidence for multicellular life way before 550 Ma, and this deserves mention

Events/narrator comments list  0:42 Theia impact and formation of Moon, begining of Hadean era 1:32 Atmosphere of Hadean Earth, no solid ground, just lava 2:05 Congrats, 90 mln years have passed 2:47 Zircons and early water on Earth 6:47 Late Heavy Bombardment (LHB) begins. Many craters on Moon and other planets formed at this period 7:12 Sun is 30% cooler than nowdays, but it's ok, cause lots of greenhouse gases are still in the Earth's atmosphere. Great place to go on vacation. 8:05 Eoarchean begins 8:15 Life emerges 8:35 Earth cools down enough for a first rain, which lasts millions of years 12:43 The cradle of Life 13:18 Paleoarchean begins, formation of continents below the water. Earth spins like a pinwheel, but do not worry, Moon will soon slow it down by it's gravity 13:42 Congrats, 1 billion years have passed 17:50 Stromatolites as a first evidence of life 18:00 Photosyntesis begins, bacterias will produce oxygen, but 99% of it goes for oxidation of various minerals (iron, etc.) That's why it took so long for GOE 18:35 Mesoarchean begins, era of continents, which constantly collide with each other 18:56 But oceans still feel like your everyday bath, 40 Celsius. Nice conditions for microbes and hell for misophobic 19:10 Anyway, you will die immediately 23:50 Neoarchean begins. Life develops further 24:34 Prokaryotes begin to expand on Earth, but no multicellular life still =( 27:46 Siderian begins, the GOE (Great Oxydation Event) is coming. During this event, most of anaerobic life died out, paving the way for aerobic life 29:38 Cause no minerals left to oxide, oxygen produced by aerobic bacterias begins to interact with methane in Earth's atmosphere, replacing it with CO2 and H2O 30:15 First glaciation arrives. First of many 30:24 Rhyacian begins 31:13 During glaciation cycles volcanos produce greenhouse gases and heat Earth. Some new stuff with melted ice comes to the oceans and gives boost to life. After that, cycle of weathering repeats and new glaciation begins again.  33:41 Orosirian begins 33:48 Impact of asteroid creates Vredefort crater, oldest and biggest (disputed by Wilkes Land crater) verified crater on Earth. It is located in RSA. 34:47 Formation of Ur, Nena and Atlantica - maybe first mountain ranges 36:57 Statherian begins 37:00 Formation of Columbia - first supercontinent ever 39:38 Calymmian begins 39:40 Somewhere here Eukaryotic cell has formed. It means an era of multicellular life has begun 41:35 Earth's crust thickens and oceans become shallower, which means more landmass can be appeared simultaneously 41:40 Fungi things by first fungi-like organisms 42:15 Ectasian begins, formation of Earth's inner core 44:51 Stenian begins, first-ever sex scene on Earth 47:30 Tonian begins, 1 bln years before nowdays, but life is still not visible 50:06 Evolution creates first predator, begining of everlasting arms race between hunters and prey. It boosts diversity even further tho 51:11 Cryogenian begins, Earth is a literally snowball. Earth freezes and un-freezes several times due to the process I've mentioned above. Check Snowball-Earth hypothesis for more info.  52:18 Ediacaran begins, formation of Gondwana supercontinent. it included Africa, South America, Antartica, Australia and some other minor parts 53:15 Life grows big and multicellar revolution begins. One of the consequences of Snowball Earth event, which leads to 53:35 Cambrian explosion, followed by Ordovician extinction 54:17 Ordovician begins 54:48 Silurian begins 55:00 Plants expand on land and create soil, eating CO2 in the process 55:07 Devonian begins 55:38 The sun is not a deadly lazer anymore, so we can go on land now 55:54 Carboniferous begins, era of forests, which will transorm into a coal burned by humans overtime 56:11 Things get faster now 56:42 Permian begins, form of Pangea, the last supercontinent 56:50 Somewhere here The Greatest Mass Extinction of All Time has happened. It opened the road for dinosaurs tho 57:20 Triassic begins, marking the begining of Dinosaur's era 57:40 oh hey, the dinosaur! 58:01 Jurassic begins, dinosaurs are at the point of their highest heyday 58:09 You can see an ancestor of pigeon running through the forest 58:46 Cretaceous begins 59:20 Earth gets more and more familiar 59:38 Chicxulub incoming and destroys a dinosaur's paradise 59:48 Paleogene begins, extinction of dinosaurs paves way for mammals 1:00:21 Neogene begins, last glaciation era started 1:00:38 Quternary begins, do not blink please 1:00:45 End

ğŸ¯ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:00 ğŸŒ Overview of Earth's Age - Earth is 4.5 billion years old, and the video aims to make this timespan comprehensible by presenting it as a one-hour musical train ride through Earth's history. 01:06 ğŸ”¥ Hadean Eon: Earth's Early Conditions - 4.5 billion years ago, in the Hadean Eon, Earth was a hell of lava with a mostly CO2 atmosphere. - The collision with Theia formed the moon, which will gradually shrink over millions of years. 08:42 ğŸŒŠ Formation of Oceans and Early Life - Oceans begin to form around 4 billion years ago, with the possibility of life originating near hydrothermal vents. - Stromatolites and evidence of early photosynthesis mark the emergence of life in the Paleoarchean. 27:57 ğŸŒ¬ï¸ Great Oxidation Event - Cyanobacteria trigger the Great Oxidation Event around 2.5 billion years ago, introducing oxygen to the atmosphere. - Oxygen reacts with methane, causing a cooling effect and initiating a period of multiple ice ages. 41:42 ğŸŒ± Evolution of Life Forms - Eukaryotic cells emerge around 1.6 billion years ago, a crucial step in the evolution of life. - The Statherian sees the formation of the supercontinent Columbia and a natural nuclear reactor. 51:25 â„ï¸ Cryogenian and the Cambrian Explosion - Earth freezes over in the Cryogenian around 720 million years ago. - The Cambrian Explosion, 539 million years ago, witnesses the rapid diversification of life forms, including the emergence of multicellular organisms. 58:02 ğŸ¦• Age of Reptiles and Mass Extinctions - The Triassic marks the age of reptiles, with dinosaurs becoming dominant. - The Permian sees Pangea forming, leading to the largest mass extinction, while the Triassic brings the asteroid that kills the dinosaurs. 59:57 ğŸŒ Paleogene to Present: Mammals and Human History - Mammals take over in the Paleogene, 66 million years ago. - Human history begins, with continents resembling today's and mammals dominating.

90% of earth's history - nothing really happens besides geology and single cell organisms. ~9.99998% remaining - the entire history of multi-cellular life before humans. 0.022% - Entire human evolution and all of human history. 0.00022% - history of human civilization since 10000 years ago.  If you keep following that it seems so obvious to me that rate of important events is so high today and still accelerating that we're basically living in singularity from evolution perspective. All of human inventions happen in a less than a millisecond of this video.  Skip ahead 1 second (1 million years!) and what we will see?  Type 3 civilization spread around universe populated by planet sized super intelligent beings? But more likely something our primitive minds can't comprehend yet?

*Question:* Would it be too financially damning to "open source" the animation/graphic files so that the community can add onto this? Maybe have an animation of the Earth's core actually growing? Add more animals and plants, perhaps with labels. Maybe make the video twice as long, but only 500k years per second.   Oh, hell, if you have the whole community contributing, why not make it enormous and do 10k per second?! (Too lazy to calculate how long the video would be.) And you could play around with acceleration (not sure how you'd "show" that), maybe for some periods keep it 1M per second, but during more interesting periods (and ones we know more about), make it even 5k per second.  Point being, is if it is actually feasible, it might be amazing to see what the community can add to this already astonishingly beautiful video.  My first thought as to why this _isn't_ possible/a good idea is because a lot of trademark stuff would make it out into the world and then the knockoffs start and you have to go all Disney on everyone. No one wants to do that, have that done to them, or have to hire the entire bar of lawyers (and have to pay them).  Still, one can dream.

It's incredible if you think about it... Notice the exponential growth in the complexity of life over time. How fortunate are we to be alive at a moment in Earth's history when that exponential growth of complex life translates into technology and our understanding of the universe? We are the result of billions of years of effort and survival, and trillions of lives fought and died, to exist in this physical form and state of love, happiness, and intelligence - the capacities of which are also on an exponential curve. I'm not religious but I love to speculate that we are the embodied consciousness of the universe waking up. We owe so much to our ancestors, even down to those single-celled organisms 3 billion years ago. This idea of an exponential rise of complexity and consciousness is more profound to me than any made-up theology.

7:23 comfy
- Earth is 4.5 billion years old - Every second, 1.5 million years pass - The Hadean eon was the first eon of Earth's history, characterized by lava and a mostly CO2 atmosphere - The moon was formed after a collision with a Mars-sized object called Theia - Life began to emerge a few hundred million years after the beginning of everything - The Great Oxidation Event paved the way for more complex life by introducing oxygen to the atmosphere - A natural, self-sustaining nuclear reactor formed 1.8 billion years ago - Around 1.6 billion years ago, the first Eukaryotic cells, cells with a nucleus, merged from two other cells

This would make for a fantastic class exercise. At the beginning of the class start the video,  and explain that this video has captured all of the history of earth and crunched it down into one class period. Then teacher would give out post it notes of different colors and have them write their names on them, and then explain that each post it color corresponds to a different major event (first dinosuars, "invention" of sex," the molten core forms, etc). There would be a time line on the board going from the start of class to the end, and over the course of the class, students are told what the events are and invited to put their post it note where they think it would be on the time line. Students could be given extra credit for getting close.
