Hi,   my name is Daniel, I am 38 years old and come from Hannover. I turn to you today, because I just have no other possibility and must now make the most unworthy of what you can imagine: begging. At 17 I found a rare spinal cord disease: an AVM - arteriovenous malformation. Normally one finds them in the head, so not with me. This is to explain it simply, a slippery sponge caused by too many small bloodlines that accumulate at a point in the case: at my spinal cord. At that time, 2002, this happened when I was on a Lan Party, and the whole weekend could not pinkle. Several investigations were then made and one decided to close these too many blood flows with a kind of glue.   When I was awakened after the surgery it happened, I couldn't move my legs properly and didn't feel it any more, so the problem with watering could not be solved until today, I had to use roughly 1 in 2000 Countless Rehas have been standing since then, but at some point I had no pleasure anymore and I started to find out that I had to go on support for my life. I was lucky and had found a woman who was also cautious and we got married in 2016. A year later, my father, while I was sitting at his hospital bed, died exactly on my 1st floor. Wedding day, on cancer. The second great depression of my life. By 2020 my mother had a stroke at work, at any rate it was believed at that time, I decided to walk with her in September 2020 the same time, it was difficult to see. My mother left the Reha after 3 weeks, I stayed two more weeks, she didn't like me all the time at all, she was somehow forgotten.   Well, when I was back at home, my mother called me and said as 1st, I will never forget this sentence, "yes, now we have the salad", she was again in MRI brain and it showed. After a sample was taken, it was found that it was a glioblastoma, the worst there is, no one survives it and most die after a year of diagnosis. My mother didn't seem to understand it so well and believed it could simply be operated out. After my birthday, in Nobember 2021, she came to a hospice where I visited her every day, I could hardly walk for any reason, so I took a woman fortan In January 2022 she left me, quasi while I was sitting on my mother's deathbed. She barely understood something and almost no longer recognized me, first the memory, then the eye light and finally her heart stopped working, finally, you have to say.   There I sat without a wife, without parents, and I have to look for an apartment by the way. I then found one, on 1.9.22 it was announced that on the day I sent my latest MRI pictures to the very well known neurosurgeon Prof. Vajkoczy by post, physiotherapy. Somehow it suddenly sounded very funny in my head and an indescribable pressure spread, all came to help, I handed myself over, suddenly the room was full of notary people and I could see nothing more. Luckily I was at the Physio. Now the cause of brain bleeding was this annoying AVM in my back, which was glued at that time, also the reason why my run became worse and worse. The sticker had completely detached and the blood shot me in my head when practicing, witty when you think about it half hour before I sent away my new pictures. Well, I had a lot of luck that was quickly traded, no lasting damage.   I was back in many rehabilitation centres and was finally operated at the top named Prof. vajkoczy in the CHariteth. Since then I have disposable nerve pains starting from the Po up to the feet, as if I had fed a pants with sandpaper. I can no longer run, do not stand up, he has "dissolved" my complete nerves, but does not, of course, allow this. A care case, with care step 4. This damned year 2022, mother, woman and the ability to run and have joy, all lost. The only thing I still have to do with my friends, as at the time at the above-mentioned Lan Party, we are still hitting today.   And there we come to my real concern, sorry I swear short, I wish so much a Gaming PC and finally a good monitor since I can think I always have the biggest Rotz mill from our round. Unfortunately, I can be a small job. Pensioners don't want to do much and ask you if you see a chance to help me? I would be infinitely grateful to you, but if not bad, ask, I thought, it costs nothing.   dear Daniel

I like the idea of uniformly speeding up the time which reminds us how short the period of the multi-cell lifeforms and not to mention the entire history of mankind is when we compare it to the history of the earth.   I wish now a video about the future of the earth. How days and months get slowly longer as the earth rotation slows down and the moon distances itself from the earth. Tectonic dynamics keep changing the surface of the earth and form new continents. As the sun continues consuming it's hydrogen for nuclear fusion, it gets very slowly but gradually lighter, subsequently the earth orbits on a longer trajectory around the sun. Nevertheless the surface temperature of the earth in long-term (over 1 billion years) increases due to the transition of the sun to a big giant, when it starts to fuse the accumulated helium in its core. Eventually, after the sun inflated to over 1000000 times of its initial size it swallows the two inner planets mercury and venus, the surface of the earth is again molten and lifeless ...   That would be also a nice complementary story to the history of earth and I trust @kurzgesagt to make another great story of that.

Great video. It really makes you appreciate a lot more what's taken for granted and skipped in academic lessons. One mistake I've noticed you keep repeating in all your videos - you use the word "chemical" as a synonym for "chemical substances". It's two entirely different terms. _Chemicals_ are products of industry, manmade substances of known composition, purity and application. _Chemical substances_ are just elementary substances or compounds.

Also, I feel that it would have been a bit more engaging to have those significant footnotes, like the crashing of tectonic plates or the forming of cellular organisms, to be displayed (and hopefully animated) while explanations are going on.  Because these footnotes often happen in a time period much shorter than the speed at which time advances in this video, a solution to that would be to remove the current timelapse for a moment, replace it with the estimated period of years this event took place, then when the explanation is over, simply switch back to how much time would have passed during that explanations, as nothing else noteworthy is often happening during these explanations.    If something else noteworthy happens during that initial explanations time, then simply explain that with another animated footnote shortly after, as the years in the corner would explain the time difference.    I realize that this is A LOT more work, and I don't expect it from this video. But, maybe this is a video that y'all could revisit in the future, with these ideas implemented. :]

copper 9
Wow! Great video! I think it's my favorite of all of your videos, though I do have a few notes / suggestions to offer. I apologize in advance for the length of this comment, but I wanted to make sure to get my points across clearly. And I also apologize for any weird phonetic typos, I am using voice typing to dictate this due to a lack of time on my part today and I don't think I'll have time to go through and edit it properly so please forgive any weird typos or non-sequiturs!  Â I realize that all of these suggestions would have added work to what was already a hugely laborious video for your team to make, and now that it is done it is very unlikely that these suggestions would be incorporated into a revised version of the video, but I'd like the video so much that I wanted to give these notes and hopefully they can be abused in designing future videos. Or if you did revise this video, I think it could be made both more informative and more watchable. The suggestions I have following the two major categories: the narration, and the illustration / animation  I'll start with the narration.  I don't doubt that adding aeration is more work than it might seem, but even with fact checking and other processes required, I imagine that it is *relatively* less work than adding illustration or animation. The narration that was present in the video was excellent, but there was room for a whole lot more of it and I think this would have made the video more watchable because long stretches of it were simply A continuing side Scroll of more or less identical looking Terrain and the narrator was not saying anything even though there are things we know about what was going on at that time that would have been both interesting and relatively non-controversial from a factual standpoint. A couple of examples: when the narrator mentioned the very large asteroid about a third of the way through the video which he said created the largest impact structure on earth, I would have loved to have gotten more info about that. Where is this impact structure? Does it still exist or have we inferred it from indirect consequences? If it does exist where on Earth is it? How big was that asteroid in relation to the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs? All of these would have been very interesting to know and there was plenty of blank space on either side of that comment so you have time to talk about it should you have wanted to. Also it would have been nice to see some evidence of the impact in the illustration instead of just being told that an asteroid impacted but then have no visible effect even though it's the largest asteroid ever. When you later covered the dinosaur asteroid, everything flashed brilliant white for a moment signaling the impact and that made it a more effective piece of information. At other times the narrator was silent for long stretches while things were happening both with life and say for instance the snowball earth. Where it froze over where that empty space could have been used to explain why we think those freezing events occurred and how certain we are about those explanations. I could go on, but I think you get the gist of what I am suggesting that the sparse narration did help communicate the long stretches of basically empty time that the Earth went through, but they did make the video harder to watch as opposed to clicking around on the phone with it in the background. More narration would have made the video more informative and more watchable, which I think would have been positive Improvement  Secondly, the animation and illustration.  The entire video was a slow side scan over either surface terrain or underwater scenery, but at various times such as when discussing the creation of continents or during the previously mentioned asteroid impact or other times when Global conditions were changing I think it would have been helpful to zoom out and see the Earth from space instead of continuing the close up side scan, which while it did change over the course of the video from second to Second it was pretty much unchanging and did not really hold my attention because I can only stare at the same scenery scrolling by for 5 minutes through an effort of will, it is not a natural inclination of mine. I realize that these suggestions would have created a lot of additional work for your animation team and that this video was being worked on in the background because I know that the Cadence of your content releases is highly important to how the algorithm treats your videos and y'all aren't able to risk slowing that came down, but hey it's a video covering 4 billion years, I think a few more months of production, assuming you were team and your business model could afford that additional production, would have made it a stronger video and like I said more informative as well as more watchable.Â   As it is, I give the video four out of five stars, simply because there are improvements that could have been made, as I've described above, and I think those would have made it to five star video, for me at least. In any case, I loved the video, I think it's my favorite one I've seen from you all so far, and I have enjoyed many of your videos, so please keep up the good work and I hope you can take these suggestions in the constructive spirit in which they are intended. I am absolutely not complaining, thank you for making a great experimental fascinating video that did indeed help me to understand how old the Earth is and how geological time works. Well done!

In my country there is a tutorial trail where they set out to do a much similar visualisation to what you guys did. That trail is 4.5 km long, and each metre is representing 1 million years of time, and at each notable event in time, there is a label at the appropriate distance. They marked out the time frame, where humans have been anywhere near being the dominant species with a ~30 cm long  piece of colourful tape

Is it just me or does Mick Gordon take over the music in at 19:40 ?
Deep time is both amazing, and terrifying at the same time. To fit 4.5 billion years into one hour, 1.5 million years had to be squeezed into each second. Yet 4.5 billion years is a blink in the possible eternity that lay ahead of us.  New stars may continue to be formed for another 100 trillion years. If we continue this same experiment, and compress the Earth's 4.5 billion years, into a single second, it would take a little over six hours to reach 100 trillion.  Think about that. A single minute would contain 270 billion years. That's 1000 times longer than the amount of time the dinosaurs reigned, in a single second, yet it would take over six hours to get to the point that the creation of stars wound down.  Played out at the same 1.5 million years a second, you would need to strap yourself in, and watch a video over 2.5 years in length.  Even this unfathomable amount of time is itself a blink in the amount of time left before all the remaining stars, long since turned into white dwarfs, and slowly cooled to the point they no longer shine, turn to iron. If that is indeed the fate of all things.   Like I said, amazing, and terrifying.
Best utilisation of 60 minutes of my lifeâ¤

Earth's early history involved a molten surface, and it collided with a Mars-sized object, which formed the moon. 02:11 ğŸ’¥ *Heavy asteroid bombardment and the emergence of life* - Earth experienced heavy asteroid bombardment during its early years, while life began to emerge in the form of the first cells. 07:19 ğŸŒŠ *Formation of oceans and potential origins of life* - Oceans began to form on Earth, and hydrothermal vents might have been the birthplace of life. 13:31 ğŸŒ± *Early evidence of life and the advent of photosynthesis* - Stromatolites provided early evidence of life, and photosynthesis may have started during this time. 18:35 ğŸŒ‹ *Formation of continents and extreme conditions* - Continents started to form, and the planet faced extreme heat and lacked oxygen. 27:57 ğŸŒ¬ï¸ *The Great Oxidation Event and ice ages* - Cyanobacteria introduced oxygen to the atmosphere, leading to the Great Oxidation Event and subsequent ice ages. 41:42 ğŸ§¬ *Emergence of Eukaryotic cells and changes in the Earth's surface* - Eukaryotic cells appeared, Earth's crust thickened, and continents took shape. 51:25 â„ï¸ *Cryogenian era and multicellular life* - Earth experienced freezing periods, but multicellular life began to flourish. 53:40 ğŸŒ *Cambrian explosion and diversification of life* - The Cambrian explosion brought a burst of life diversity, including the emergence of various animal groups. 56:14 ğŸŒ² *Rise of forests, coal formation, and rapid changes* - Forests and lush marshlands thrived, leading to the formation of coal. 58:02 ğŸ¦• *Age of dinosaurs and asteroid impact* - My complaints as I'm watching are as follows: Says that photosynthesis might have started as early as the start of the mesoarchean, immediately says there are no photosynthesizers iirc mass oxygenation became a problem because there was too much oxygen for life, causing a mass extinction. This isn't brought up in the slightest. Pays no mind to the Krebs cycle Brings up massive impactor with zero payoff Algaebanjowarfopubescence is brought up and given zero explanation. I have no clue what this is and only have questions.  Cryogenian immediately asks how life could have survived earth freezing over again. Says that we don't know. My immediate thought is that, much like lakes, it just froze the surface and a few meters deep. This would never have killed off all life at this time. Mentions variety if life in Cambrian, shows 2 creatures. Says the atmosphere was only oxygenated in the silurian. This is false. "Fish and first vertebrate" fish are vertebrates. Blames volcanoes for Permian extinction. iirc we do not actually know why the Permian extinction occurred.   The video was mostly great, yall did great, even if I was a bit nitpicky. If you can make the little improvements to your writing that would fix these small issues that would be awesome, keep up the good work either way!

Crazy how long it takes for life to be created.
I remember watching VSauce's "Our Narrow Slice" video several years ago, where they dedicated the last ~2 minutes to moving forward 1 millenia per second since the beginning of humans (200,000 years ago), and I found it to be one of the coolest efforts to conceptualize our... narrow slice in time. Everything except the last couple seconds was a whole lot of nothing. Primitive agriculture, ancient Romans, and ancient Egyptians all evolved very quickly for a few seconds at the end, and then modern civilization as we know it seemed to be a single frame. And that was just spanning the lifetime of MODERN humans, a mere 200,000 years ago. This video takes that concept to a whole new level. Our infinitesimally small droplet of a droplet in the ocean of an unfathomable elapsed amount of time (and even more time to come) is something we'll never be able to truly grasp, but I love attempts like this to do so. It makes me feel so special and insignificant at the same time, and I think that's a beautifully complicated feeling everyone should try to attach to the very core of their being. Our privilege to live in such an incomprehensibly wondrous universe on such a beautiful planet at such an interesting time is too often taken for granted.

It's fascinating to see how many extinction level events have happened wiping out all of life on the planet, but yet a few million years later and it's back stronger and more complex. I interpret it almost as if life is the the universes laws of matter moving towards equilibrium. Kind of like gradient descent but at the scale of the universe. It makes me wonder about all the trillions of other planets out there. If a few multi-cellular organisms can pop up here with some basic inorganic compounds and survive dozens of extinction level events, it's hard to believe that we are alone in this wonderous and vast cosmos.

AT 17:56 there is a huge mistake. The oceans at the time were RED because the first ever algal organisms had an iron composition before consuming co2 from the atmosphere and releasing oxygen from photosynthesis. The ocean would gradually become green but at the time it red. When photosynthesis occurred over time the red algae would drop their iron structure and create the first ever iron red beds in the archean lithology.  - Geology student in Mount Royal University

The cost breakdown includes $8 trillion for bamboo, $1 trillion for labor, and $1 trillion for infrastructure, with a 35-year cycle for replacing bamboo and sustaining the initiative. The equation representing the total cost () is , where $10 trillion is the initial funding, $8 trillion is for the bamboo plants, $1 trillion is for labor costs, and $1 trillion is for infrastructure costs.  is the number of bamboo plants,  is the labor costs for every 35 years after the first initial bamboo implementation, and  is the revenue from selling the mature bamboo. Assuming an average selling price of $5 for each mature bamboo plant, the revenue from selling all 1.6 trillion 35-year-old bamboo plants would be $8 trillion. It is important to note that the success of this model depends on several factors, including the availability of sufficient land for planting, global cooperation from the majority of governments contributing to their greenhouse gas emissions, an ample workforce for labor, consistent pricing throughout the 35-year period, successful selling and buying of the bamboo, and other logistical and operational considerations. Every time something is said:  0:00 0:08  0:14  0:25  0:33  0:41 Pretty early in its history, Earth collides with a Mars sized object called Theia, 0:47 which forms the moon that you now see in the sky. 0:53 Right now it looks huge in the night sky and will slowly shrink over hundreds of millions 0:59 of years as it orbits further away. 1:06 4.5 Billion Years Ago we are in the first eon of our planet, the Hadean, named after the greek god of the underworld. 1:32 At this point the Atmosphere is mostly CO2 and the floor is lava. 1:39 This area of earth's history is mostly invisible to us because almost none of it is left. 2:06 90 million years have passed. We are still in the lava hell phase. 2:11 Settle in, this will take a while. 2:47 Although you wouldn't think it, we found minerals called zircons that indicate 2:52 there may have been some water around at this time. 6:48 During this period of the young solar system, Earth and the inner solar system are smashed by a constant heavy asteroid bombardment, for several hundred million years. 7:12 At this point in time, our Sun is 30% less bright than it is today but there are so many 7:19 greenhouse gases that it's still much hot and comfy. Eoarchean 8:16 Around this time we think life begins to enter the stage. 8:21 Only a few hundred million years after the beginning of everything the first cells begin 8:27 spreading over our still very deadly planet. 8:37 Earth continues to cool and it probably rains for millions of years as our oceans begin to form, covering the still young planet with water. 12:43 These hydrothermal vents we're looking at, and where hot minerals emerge, may have been 12:49 the place where life first developed, but we dont know. 13:18 So much time has passed and we are entering the Paleoarchean. Paleoarchean 13:23 Most of Earth is still underwater while the first supercontinents are in the making 13:29 in the depths below. Its days are shorter since the young Earth spins faster. 13:42 Good job if you are still watching. You witnessed a billion years so far. 17:49 From this time in history we still have Stromatolites, sedimentary rocks built by microorganisms. 17:56 Among our first real evidence of life on Earth. Also life is starting to eat the sun â€“ photosynthesis might have started as early as around here. Mesoarchean 18:35 3.2 Billion Years Ago in the Mesoarchean the era of continents begins. 18:42 Tectonic plates begin to crush into each other, pulling and pushing some deep into the earth 18:48 where they dissolve. The basis for our continents today. 18:54 The oceans are as hot as a hottub, over 40Â°C and microbes are expanding everywhere. 19:03 We don't have plants yet to consume greenhouse gases, so it is really, really hot. 19:10 You would basically die immediately in this atmosphere. Also there is no oxygen in the atmosphere yet. Neoarchean 23:51 2.8 Billion Years Ago the Neoarchean begins. Earth is still a terribly hostile place but because we finally have proper plate tectonics, 24:02 more chemicals are mixed in from inside the earth and life can use them to make new things! 24:34 Some time around here Prokaryotes like bacteria begin colonizing the planet. 24:40 Life diversifies more and more. But still, after so much time, we only have single cells. 27:46 2.5 Billion Years Ago in the Siderian, a massive event is about to begin Siderian 27:52 that will change the planet forever: The Great Oxidation Event. 27:57 Oxygen, burped out by cyanobacteria reaches the atmosphere in large quantities, 28:03 paving the way for more complex life. 29:39 All the new oxygen in the air reacts with methane and forms CO2 and Water, 29:44 which rapidly cools the planet down. 30:16 Probably for the first time ever, the planet freezes over and a period of multiple 30:21 ice ages begins lasting millions of years. Rhyacian 30:27 2.3 Billion Years Ago the Rhyacian begins. 31:14 Lots of volcanos heat up earth and earth unfreezes slowly again. 31:20 Melting ice flushes toxic elements into the oceans but life quietly puts up resistance 31:27 and keeps evolving. Orosirian 33:48 Some time 2.05 Billion Years Ago in the Orosirian a large asteroid hits earth and creates the 33:56 largest verified impact structure on Earth. 34:47 All over Earth great mountain ranges are crushed into existence by early continents 34:52 with wild names like Ur, Nena or Atlantica. Statherian 37:00 1.8 Billion Years Ago in the Statherian the supercontinent Columbia has formed. 37:06 And a natural, self sustaining nuclear reactor awakes, just from scattered uranium deposits in the ground. 39:37 1.6 billion years ago, around the edge of Calimmian, + or - a few hundred million years or so, Calymmian 39:44 the first Eukaryotic cells, cells with a nucleus, merge from two other cells. 39:50 One of the most important moments in the history of life. But yes, kind of looks not that impressive. 39:59 Still, life is only cells. 41:35 Earth's crust thickens and heavy continents form, the oceans become shallower. 41:42 Also the first fungi-like organisms extent their tubular arms and do fungi things. Ectasian 42:17 Some time in the Ectasian 1.4 Billion Years Ago, Earths inner core is forming. 42:24 Weird, right? Feels like it should be older. But around here it begins to solidify into a iron crystal surrounded by hot liquid metal. 42:34 It will only grow from now on. Stenian 44:53 1.2 Billion Years Ago in the Stenian not that much is going on. 44:59 Except, the algae Bangiomorpha pubescens might have invented sex. 45:05 A big reproductive improvement for many different reasons. Tonian 47:33 1 Billion Years Ago the Tonian begins, another age where Earth is rocks and puddles and oceans. 47:42 Life is still invisible to the naked eye. It does feel different to witness it like that, right? 50:07 Not everybody is having a great time here. We have evidence of the first unicellular predators emerging around that time. 50:16 The dominance of bacteria ends and big boy eukaryotes plant their flags in the oceans. An arms race between microbes begins that again creates huge diversity. 50:29 Some even invent tiny armour. Cryogenian 51:14 720 Million Years Ago in the Cryogenian Earth freezes over again. 51:21 Sure why not. How did life survive? We are not sure. Ediacaran 52:19 635 Million Years Ago the supercontinent Gondwana forms. 52:24 A lot of it is still left today! 53:15 Wow! What's happening? Suddenly life gets big! In a hot second multicellular organisms become widespread! 53:24 It's all strange aliens still, but can you imagine that it took that long for this to happen? Cambrian 53:35 539 Million Years Ago the Cambrian explosion begins. 53:40 We see life bursting with variety. Ancestors of almost all of today's major animal groups appear here while the plants start 53:49 to discover the land. Life is finally exciting! 53:54 But of course a big mass extinction happens right after, killing most species in the ocean. Silurian 55:01 Plants spread over the planet and create the soil on the ground and change the atmosphere 55:07 by eating CO2. Devonian 55:38 Things escalate. Flora and fauna adapt better and better to life on land. 55:45 We get trees and forrests, fish and the first vertebrate decide this land thing 55:51 is something they need to try out! Carboniferous 55:56 359 Million Years Ago in the Carboniferous forests and lush marshlands are at their peak. 56:05 They will turn into the coal humanity burns today to keep ourselves warm. 56:12 Its all so fast now! Life changes so quickly in geological timeframes! 56:42 Some 299 Million Years Ago in the Permian, Pangea, the last supercontinent has formed. Permian 56:50 And after a few tens of million years, the largest mass extinction in history happens, 56:56 killing the majority of all species. Thanks volcanoes. Triassic 57:23 252 Million Years Ago the Triassic begins. 57:41 Oh hey, a dinosaur! Jurassic 58:02 We are now truly in the age of reptiles. Dinosaurs are everywhere! 58:08 The ancestors of the birds do bird things. Life, uhh, finds a way! Cretaceous 59:20 Earth gets more and more familiar. 59:38 Such a paradise. Life is thriving. Nothing can go wrong... wait, what's that? Paleogene 59:50 And an asteroid killed the dinosaurs and most species on Earth. Such a bummer. 59:57 66 Million Years Ago in the Paleogene the continents look roughly the same as today and mammals take over. 1:00:06 It is our time now! We are almost home. Quaternary 1:00:39 Don't blink or you might miss all of human history! Ending 1:00:45 And that was it. Earth is ancient. We are new. 1:00:51 So new. This was a project born of passion. We've worked on this video on and off since 2019 and as you can imagine, it took forever to make. 1:01:01 But we did we finished it in time for our tenth10 year anniversary. If you want to support experimental videos like this one please like, share and subscribe 1:01:09 and press the bell. You can also continue your journey through time with our new Timeline of Evolution poster. 1:01:15 Discover how long it took for the first cellular blobs to evolve into fishes, then into dinosaurs, and finally into mammals â€“ and encounter amazing creatures you've never heard of along the way. 1:01:24 This poster is part of our Education Edition. A poster series that brings complex topics to life through extensive research and 1:01:31 elaborate illustrations. Itâ€™s perfect for teachers, students, and science lovers. Get them from our shop and support what we do on this channel. 1:01:38 In any case, if you got this far, thank you so much! Hope you felt something watching this.

On average we blink our eyes about once every four seconds. On average a species will exist for about five million years before going extinct. At this time-scale those two time-spans are about the same. The actual blink of an eye itself lasts about 0.1 to 0.15 seconds, which in this video would represent 125,000 to 187,500 years. He wasnâ€™t kidding when he said donâ€™t blink or you might miss all of human history. (And the current average human lifespan would be 0.056 milliseconds here) (Also there would be about 50,000 generations of humans every second)

57:21 Long ago, before dinosaurs appeared, the world experienced the greatest extinction of living organisms in the history of life on our planet. On Earth, the Permian extinction occurred, 90% of animal and plant species left our family tree forever, but a lucky few managed to survive them. One of them was a small herbivore about the size of a domestic pig, a therapsid. Its name was Lystrosaurus. He ruled the supercontinent Pangea for nearly 4 MILLION YEARS. After the Permian extinction, it had no more natural enemies for the next few million years... It lived a crisp and peaceful life in the wastelands of Pangaea. It conquered all lands and at one point 80% of all land vertebrates were of its genus. No genre before or since has achieved such success... However, one day an evil Gorgonops appeared, a powerful prehistoric lizard weighing 1 ton and 3 meters long. He became the doom of the Lystrosaurus. After millions of years of idyllic life, Lystrosaurus lost its survival instinct. Lystrosaurs became the Dodo birds of their day. It simply disappeared from the surface of the Blue Planet, but 1/4 of a billion years later a certain species of primate (that's what I'm writing about us) found its fossils forgotten in prehistory... what am I getting at? Everyone has lived and everyone will cease to live forever. But that doesn't mean it won't cease to exist. Man ceases to live forever, but as long as he is remembered, he still EXISTS.

4.5 billion years in 1 hour - each second represents 1.25 million years, which means the entire human history was a split second at the end of the video. So let's take the last second and repeat the process. In the NEW 1 hour video each second represents roughly 350 years. Therefore the entire human history, or the last 10,000 years, will still be just half a minute at the end.

Posting this comment shortly after the billion year mark, and I'm thinking to myself as I'm watching this, fully intending to watch this with my undivided attention all the way through, that if the dinosaurs lasted 165 million years that ended around 65-66 million years ago, I'm not going to see much of classic "dinosaur" imagery until the last 5 or 6 minutes or so of this whole hour+ long transitional video, and the dinosaurs themselves will last just under 3 minutes before the earth returns to being in a hellscape for a short time, and that humans will only be in the very last second. All of humans. All of human history condensed down to a singular second to put into perspective how long the rest of earth's history truly is.  This is a marvel of a video already, and I can't wait to witness the rest of it. Congrats on 10 years!!! Just some constructive criticism:  I did not like scrolling through this video to find the parts where you spoke. Either some kind of indicator to know when the next informational talk was going to come in, or to have more varied visuals so that it is not a chore to watch the same area go by. I noticed that some of the dialogue coincides with the era changing so I could use the timestamps to find the next informational dialogue, but there were multiple dialogue sections that I may have missed by skipping over the looping visuals.  I did not see much value in making it a 1 hr video to showcase the relative difference in the time of each era. Personally I would have appreciated this video being presented in the usual way rather than me having to scroll through the video trying to find the next dialogue bit.

I'm sorry, what?! An hour long Kurzgesagt video?! Wow. Thank you!  Edit: Not what I expected, but lovely all the same.
I've been wanting a long-form Kurzgesagt video for so long. I know how much time and effort goes into your animations and research even on the 10 minute video scale, but it can feel exhausting to keep up - especially when you jump from one really cool idea to immediately to another. I don't mind slower or repeated animations and spaced out writing. This still feels lightly engaging, while also avoiding that frantic elevator pitch feeling that I get from so many YouTube videos these days.  On the opposite end of the spectrum, I absolutely love History of the Universe's channel. Yes, his hour-long videos are normally just voice recordings overtop a repeating abstract background animation, but the pace of his writing and speaking is super comfortable.

@37:05 - Nice work @Kurzgesagt!  I was amazed and pleasantly surprised to see you mention Earth's first nuclear fission reactor - it was about 1.7B years ago and completely natural.  If anyone is wondering how - it is because U235 decays faster than U238, and in order to get reactors to work today in ordinary "light" water, you need enrichment to increase the ratio of U235 in the fuel (typically 3-5% on new fuel).  Because of the difference in uranium decay rates, there was more U235 around back then, about 3% vs the 0.7% today, so a natural nuclear reactor from it was possible and did happen.  If anyone wants to see what nuclear waste looks like after 1.7B years ago (no real damage but it is cool) look up the "Oklo natural nuclear reactor".

This is a MASTERPIECE
Thank you! What i love about videos like this is PERSPECTIVE. How many people watching this were shocked to learn that all the interesting animal/plant stuff happens in the last like 7 and a half MINUTES of an hour long video about Earth's history?! Or that the freaking dinosaurs went extinct barely over a minute before the end?! Or that human existence (not recorded history, ENTIRE EVOLUTIONARY EXISTENCE) is barely a second or two?! Even having known this before hand, it's ALWAYS remarkable to see!  I remember when i first learned that the Cambrian Explosion happened LESS THAN half a billion years ago and yet the earth is 4.6 billion old and life is 3.8 (less maybe?), meaning that the appearance of all modern major animal groups happened in less than 1/9th of the time earth has existed!  I remember being confused, like "that seems like a lot of time worth of single-celled nothingness, then all the sudden everything else appears in an instant"! But that was ignorance on my part, because within those billions of years of "nothingness" so many important single-celled milestones happened that, eventually, ALLOWED that explosion of diversity to happen in the Cambrian.   We needed an oxygen rich and temporate climate from photosynthesis, development of bacteria vs archaea vs viruses, MULTIPLE symbiosis events especially for mitochondria and chloroplasts (Eukaryotes), sexual reproduction, predation, cells sticking/cooperating together for multi-cellularism, cell specialization and tissues, among many other things I cant even think of cuz im a layman haha. Not to mention the initial innovations after abiogenesis (lipid cell wall to encapsulate the cell, use of naturally occuring amino acids to make countless kinds of proteins, RNA then DNA to store genetic info, using an energy source for food, and finding a way to reproduce ALL OF THIS for the next generation).  Only AFTER you have all this can a Cambrian Explosion even happen, and these previous steps were all major innovations and thus took TIME and transition (something I foolishly overlooked). The Cambrian Explosion didnt innovate THAT much in a sense (other than animal diversity, but we're animals so we're biased haha). It took advantage of fundamental systems that single-celled life developed over EONS, which in turn allowed the diversity explosion to happen in a relatively short amount of time!  tl;dr: we have a lot of thanks owed to singled celled life working over eons to innovate on life, its what allowed the Cambrian Explosion to happen so swiftly!  Thanks for this amazing video!

It allowed cells to become hundreds of times bigger and infinitely more complex. In comparison, multicellularity was a cake walk and it has happened several times independently.

In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. Now the earth was formless and void, and darkness was over the surface of the deep. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the waters. And God said, â€œLet there be light,â€ and there was light. And God saw that the light was good, and He separated the light from the darkness. (All before the video) God called the light â€œday,â€ and the darkness He called â€œnight.â€ And there was evening, and there was morningâ€”the first day. And God said, â€œLet there be an expanse between the waters, to separate the waters from the waters.â€ So God made the expanse and separated the waters beneath it from the waters above (8:36-12:36). And it was so. God called the expanse â€œsky.â€ And there was evening, and there was morningâ€”the second day. And God said, â€œLet the waters under the sky be gathered into one place, so that the dry land may appear.â€ And it was so (18:35-34:47). God called the dry land â€œearth,â€ and the gathering of waters He called â€œseas.â€ And God saw that it was good. Then God said, â€œLet the earth bring forth vegetation: seed-bearing plants and fruit trees, each bearing fruit with seed according to its kind.â€ And it was so (17:59-27:47). The earth produced vegetation: seed-bearing plants according to their kinds and trees bearing fruit with seed according to their kinds. And God saw that it was good. And there was evening, and there was morningâ€”the third day. And God said, â€œLet there be lights in the expanse of the sky to distinguish between the day and the night, and let them be signs to mark the seasons and days and years. And let them serve as lights in the expanse of the sky to shine upon the earth.â€ And it was so. God made two great lights: the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night (0:43). And He made the stars as well. God set these lights in the expanse of the sky to shine upon the earth, to preside over the day and the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good. And there was evening, and there was morningâ€”the fourth day. And God said, â€œLet the waters teem with living creatures, and let birds fly above the earth in the open expanse of the sky.â€ So God created the great sea creatures and every living thing that moves (53:35), with which the waters teemed according to their kinds, and every bird of flight after its kind. And God saw that it was good. Then God blessed them and said, â€œBe fruitful and multiply and fill the waters of the seas, and let birds multiply on the earth.â€ And there was evening, and there was morningâ€”the fifth day. And God said, â€œLet the earth bring forth living creatures according to their kinds: livestock, land crawlers, and beasts of the earth according to their kinds.â€ And it was so (55:38). God made the beasts of the earth according to their kinds, the livestock according to their kinds, and everything that crawls upon the earth according to its kind. And God saw that it was good. Then God said, â€œLet Us make man in Our image, after Our likeness, to rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the livestock, and over all the earth itself and every creature that crawls upon it.â€ So God created man in His own image; in the image of God He created him; male and female He created them (1:00:39). God blessed them and said to them, â€œBe fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth and subdue it; rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air and every creature that crawls upon the earth.â€ Then God said, â€œBehold, I have given you every seed-bearing plant on the face of all the earth, and every tree whose fruit contains seed. They will be yours for food. And to every beast of the earth and every bird of the air and every creature that crawls upon the earthâ€”everything that has the breath of life in itâ€”I have given every green plant for food.â€ And it was so. And God looked upon all that He had made, and indeed, it was very good. And there was evening, and there was morningâ€”the sixth day.

THIS IS A GOATED VIDEO
Imagine a drummer that is playing that beat. Every second he hits the drum. One second is one Million Years, the video is one hour long. Lets suppose the drummer needs to move his hand 1 Meter from one beat to the next. 1 hour in 1 Million years is the 0,000000000114th part of it. That means, as you watched the video, the drummer moved his hand 114 Picometer on his swing for his next million year drum beat. 114 Picometer are just barely enough to be registered by an electron microscope or roughly 4 hydrogen atoms in width.
Crazy how you compiled 4.5 billlion years into 1 hour, I wonder how much content was missed

Is the music available as a download?
So, questions... 1. Between the first and second periods, how did it go from raining fire to raining, well, rain? And was it more like acid rain because the atmosphere was so greenhouse gassy? Did things just cool down enough for that to happen? If so, how?  2. You talk early on, in the section where it's still raining fire but starting to rain rain, about the ingredients  for life potentially being present. Does that indicate that the ingredients came in on the meteors? Like we're all "aliens", so to speak, since what initially made up everything didn't originate here?  3. Earth used to spin faster? How did it slow down? I thought gravity was a constant? I mean, I ASSUME that's at least part of what keeps it in rotation, but I could be mistaken.  4. I know that, in the early stages, we're not talking daisies and tigers and humans, but how did even prehistoric life sustain itself under such hostile conditions? Do we know?  5. Wait, what? How did the bacteria produce oxygen if...there...was no oxygen...? Now I'm confused. THIS is how much you don't learn in Catholic school science, good Gods.  6. How many Ice Ages were there/ Because we are NOT talking the one that ended 12,000-ish years ago that split Asia off from North America. That whole theory about the Indigenous crossing the land bridge is BS, by the way. They've been here (I'm Canadian) WAY longer than that. Try about 100,000 years, which is how their genomes have diversified so much from anyone in Asia. Those sorts of differences couldn't evolve in just 12,000 years.  7. How did life survive the second really big Ice Age? Since it wasn't multicellular yet, and didn't need to breathe, though it did still need oxygen, I wonder if the survivors of the initial freeze didn't go underwater and hang out and reproduce under the ice sheet for a few thousand years? That's my best guess.  8. Potentially stupid question, but when did the day-night cycle start? I mean visibly? I assume that was after the atmosphere formed and the sky turned blue, but I'm not sure.  9. Uh, YEAH, I'm willing to believe this one took forever. Happy anniversary!

Amazing video!  I'm disappointed that we get zero mention of biota like the Francevillian biota. Complex life emerged longer ago, before the Ediacaran - it was just cut short by all the ice ages.  Also no shots of the Moon with an atmosphere and water. Or the Canfield ocean.  It would also have rained earlier, as early as 4.4 Gya and it would have been a long process. So the whole Eoarchaean shot likely would have transpired earlier and in a shorter timeframe, from 4.4 to 4 Gya. Earth probably started off with an extremely thick atmosphere after Theia, blotting out any features in the sky and tinting everything in yellow like Venus. So rain would have started off as virga until enough CO2 was sequestered that it cooled to the point of allowing liquid water to exist at the surface. And this likely would have been at high temperatures but also elevated pressures.  The first photosynthesizers were probably not all green but incorporated other colors like purple. These kinds of bacteria still exist today, they just got outcompeted by cyanobacteria.  The Ordovician and Silurian are also quite sparse, and Devonian cephalopods actually emerged during the Ordovician.  Still, it's otherwise a great video.
To all viewers reading this comment, we are very lucky and fortunate enough to be able to born in this era where we can consume this type of content for free. Lets take a moment to appreciate it ğŸ™‚ğŸ™‚ğŸ¤ğŸ¤

I'm sorry but this video is flawed in a few ways.  The grammatical error by the narrator near the end of the first section. The fact that you have 4.5 billion years of information available but can't fill an hour video with dialog, leaving incredibly long gaps of "dead air"(ignoring the music) but, on the music, why is this music the same type used in videos meant to be played as background noise? It makes it impossible to pay attention to the entire video without missing quite a lot of the sparse dialog because you're zoned out since it's been over a minute since anything but generic music was playing.  I understand that you wanted to put the time line in perspective. But this video could have sped up the time line to match the amount of time that the narrator was speaking about each era, cutting out all the unnecessary "dead air". Or.. all dialog could have been cut and this could just have been a screen saver.. trying to do both takes away from both.

The floor is lava!
There is so much to talk about this video, there are so many hidden things and facts you notice, remember and link up from across Youtube and the internet and everything you have learnt, and even if the video is silent and slow, your brain sort of fills in the gaps and puts everything you personally know into them. Spoilers below, I want you to watch the video and make your own observations before reading mine.  1. The contrast between this video and bill wurtz's history of the world is amazing. This video is much more relaxed, slow paced (until the final few eras). Bill does an amazing job, and his video is supercharged, superfast and you have to pay very close attention and know a lot of things beforehand already.  Note: I am looking at this video from a naturalist perspective, so the further observations might have some bias, so take any opinions with a grain of salt.  2. This video, particularly the multiple asteroid bombardments, ice ages and asteroid strikes in the Orosirian (33:48) and the Cretaceous (59:45) make me think of Fermi's Paradox and the Great Filter solution to the Fermi Paradox, how there are so many different things that might be a filter to life, and then to intelligent life.   3. Early forms of life (RNA, perhaps) begins around 8:30, then better unicellular life 12:40, and around 18:00 we get Photosynthesis, but it takes until 39:43 to get to Eukaryotes, which are still unicellular. 44:53 we get SEX! But we only get multicellular life until 52:55 and then the Cambrian explosion (remember the jingle from bill wurtz? Also the Evodevo song from AcepellaScience)  Imagine watching a 1 hour movie but the plot only starts at minute 53? And the twist happens at 59:46? That's one crazy movie. For all the people who claim that it is HIGHLY unlikely for life to form out of random chance, I ask you, if you were playing the lottery every second with millions of molecules for 3 billion years, why wouldn't you win it?  3.5. Hey, don't forget the Great Oxygenation event happened at 27:50 in the Siderean.  4. Visually, for me, the Calymmian Era is the best. Which one did you like?   5. I haven't watched the video enough to give a fair judgement on the best soundtrack, but I think Mesoarchean slaps. Although there might be better ones I forgot or missed.  6. It's so funny to know the names of all eras after the Cambrian, having heard and read it so many times all over the science side of the internet.   7. It is bizzare to think the Hadean Era was just asteroid rain, where each second we wait, the Earth waited for 1.5 million years. More than humanity has lived, EACH SECOND. Surreal.  8. If you pause fast enough you can see the things inside the living beings in the Neoarchean. That's cool.  9. Some of the Eras feel like Sci-fi planets from some verses. And they last for millions of years. Makes me wonder if all the planets described in Halo/StarWars/StarTrek/DoctorWho/WH40K are just in one of the phases of the planet's evolution. Maybe some of the exoplanets we see today are in their early or late stages of life. Maybe that's the answer (The Not enough time has passed solution to the Fermi Paradox) as to why we don't see planets with habitable life. Earth itself looked like an alien, inhospitable planet for so long.  10. The Cryogenian freezes multiple times, reminding me of how bill wurtz said that the earth 'froze multiple times, probably'.  I also noted some interesting tidbits, and I want myself to be corrected on this if I am wrong:  a. We depart from the moon in the Hadean Era around 7:00 and we don't see it until 37:23 in the Statherian Era. Then lose it about 42:00 in the Calymmian. We see a Crescent moon at 58:46 in the Cretaceous Era, then disappears at 59:07. I don't see it after this. b. We see the sun first at 17:55 in the Paleoarchean and depart from it in 23:20 in the Mesoarchean, then Calymmian 42:08 to 47:00 in the Stenian Era. I don't see the sun after this. c. I kind of want to also make a list of all Eras underwater and overwater, but that is too much work right now ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜” d. The Eoarchean 8:10 is the first Era he doesn't say the name of. I expected it to be later. e. The Ordovician 54:17 is the first Era without any introduction or even any commentary. f. I also want to mark all of the supercontinents, but I forgot where they were... Pangea is about 56:45  I want to come back and find more things about this video later. Thanks so much @kurzgesagt!

The visuals as always are great, but the music! By the gods, the music was perfect! Each 4-beat lasting exactly 5 million years, perfectly pacing the time elapsing, and with each era having its own musical leitmotifs and all in a continual DJ mix - if they give awards for music in web videos, this should win it.   One quibble - we go around the Milky Way once every quarter-billion years or so, and there would have been some changes to the star field and some supernovae happening. I'd have had the star background scroll when that was on display, have the occasional star appear, have the occasional star go out in a massive explosion in the sky. Even if it were three layers moving at slightly different speeds, that would have scratched an itch for me. But I'm complaining about something that must have taken months to plan and produce. Just the idea of using a Voronoi diagram at 23:20 to animate the surface of the sea, little touches like that, were beautiful.

The flavor, music and everything can be heard, tasted, seen and felt from a screen. You can really hear the breaths between the music artist, empathizing her love for this rotating bacon. I think this would have to have 64,782,996,588,822 views for it to be watched for an equivalent amount of time. (I know I donâ€™t account for leap years) The math: 60Ã—60=3600 (second in an hour) 3600Ã—24=86400 (seconds in a day) 86400Ã—365=31,536,000 (seconds in a year) 31,536,000Ã—4,500,000,000= 2.46888e17 (seconds in 4.5b years) (big number my calculator can't write out) Now we find out how many second in this video (60Ã—63+31=3811 (seconds in this video) Divide the amount of seconds in 4.5b years by how long this videos length in seconds and you get how many times this has to be viewed 2.46888e17/3811= 64,782,996,588,821.83 rounded up because you can't get .83 people  to get: 64,782,996,588,822

While this video is great, it lacks information. Sure, i know whats happening visually, oh water's rising, oh that is a sponge, oh the moon is getting farther, etc. Most of us watching aren't scientists, and most of us (hopefully) are here to learn, i may know whats going on visually, but i want to know it in details. Whats happening chemically, physically, biologically and from other scientific prospective. Examples such as why did it take long for life to evolve? The earth core formed very later on, why? What are the details of the biggest mass extinction? And so on. And one point, the ballance is falwed in my opinion. The first eon where earth was hell like planet didn't have a lot of details (at least that we know about) unlike the later eons that contained life, so by giving them all the same ratio is a bit flawed.  Great video however, i appreciate your work and will continue supporting it.

17:55 The green colour isn't just the art. In an atmosphere without oxygen, erosion of iron in the ocean as Fe2+ ions, stains the oceans a green colour. After photosynthesis, the green Fe2+ is oxidized by Oxygen in brown Fe3+, creating the Banded Iron Formations you see in 27:45   30:20 photosynthesis by Cyanobacteria removes so much CO2, a greenhouse gas, from the atomsphere that it sends the whole earth into global cooling, an event known as Snowball Earth.

Truly incredible, kurzgesagt on a Friday rocks! 00:00 ğŸŒ The Earth is 4.5 billion years old, and its entire history is compressed into a one-hour video to illustrate the vastness of geological time. 00:30 ğŸŒ‹ Early Earth, just after formation, was a molten hellscape, colliding with Theia to form the Moon. 01:06 ğŸ”¥ The Hadean eon, characterized by a CO2-rich atmosphere and lava-covered surface, is mostly undocumented in geological history. 02:11 ğŸŒ§ï¸ Despite a dimmer Sun, Earth's high greenhouse gas levels kept it warm, possibly with early water and heavy asteroid bombardment. 07:19 ğŸ§« The emergence of life, possibly near hydrothermal vents, occurs just a few hundred million years after Earth's formation. 13:31 â±ï¸ Earth's days were shorter in its early history due to faster rotation. 17:39 ğŸª¨ Stromatolites provide some of the earliest evidence of life on Earth. 18:00 ğŸŒ The onset of photosynthesis marks a significant evolutionary development. 18:22 ğŸŒ The Mesoarchean era witnesses the beginning of continental formation and tectonic activity. 19:14 ğŸš« Early Earth's atmosphere lacked oxygen, making it inhospitable for humans. 24:35 ğŸ¦  Prokaryotes like bacteria begin colonizing the planet, showing increased biodiversity. 28:04 ğŸŒ¬ï¸ The Great Oxidation Event introduces oxygen into the atmosphere, paving the way for complex life. 30:16 â„ï¸ The planet experiences its first ice ages due to the cooling effects of atmospheric changes. 34:11 â›°ï¸ Formation of early mountain ranges and continents like Ur, Nena, or Atlantica. 37:03 ğŸŒ The supercontinent Columbia forms, and natural nuclear reactions occur due to uranium deposits. 39:43 ğŸ§¬ The emergence of Eukaryotic cells, a major evolutionary milestone, occurs approximately 1.6 billion years ago. 42:17 ğŸŒ The Earth's inner core begins to solidify around 1.4 billion years ago. 45:04 ğŸ’ The organism Bangiomorpha pubescens possibly invents sexual reproduction. 50:08 ğŸ›¡ï¸ The emergence of unicellular predators and an arms race among microbes. 53:15 ğŸŸ The Cambrian explosion marks the rapid diversification of life and the advent of major animal groups. 56:43 ğŸŒ‹ The largest mass extinction in history occurs in the Permian period, caused by volcanic activity. 57:33 ğŸ¦• The rise of dinosaurs begins in the Triassic period. 59:38 ğŸŒ³ Mammals rise to prominence after the extinction of dinosaurs 66 million years ago. 01:00:30 ğŸ•’ Human history, by comparison, is just a blink in Earth's long timeline.
